Worldwide Africa: Fashioning Personhood
exhibition_description: Through the eyes of nine talented African artists this exhibition explores notions of personal style and cultural identity in contemporary Africa. Worldwide Africa: Fashioning Personhood challenges conventional ideas of African aesthetics and personhood. As in the larger African art galleries, the theme of mobility and the wide circulation of ideas and influences from within and without the continent characterize the work of young African artists and designers. Their contemporary innovative work highlights the international reach of the African continent, featuring the rich exchange of African creativity with global cultures, periods, and styles.

Sweden: A Royal Treasury 1550-1700
exhibition_description: This exhibition explored one of the most extraordinary and little known periods in European history.  Comprising 125 objects acquired by Swedish kings and queens during the country's ascendance in the 16th and 17th centuries when it reigned as a great power in Europe, the exhibition symbolized the extent and luster of Swedish influence during its period of greatest glory.  Many of the works of art--chiseled armor and inlaid firearms, royal costumes embroidered in gold and silver, diamond-encrusted crowns--left Sweden for the first time.  The exhibition, organized by the Institute in collaboration with the National Gallery, Washington, D.C., also traveled to Washington, D.C. and the Royal Academy of Arts, London.

exhibition_title: Objects of Bright Pride: Northwest Coast Indian Art from the American Museum of Natural History
exhibition_description: Ceremonial masks, speakers' staffs, shamans' rattles and charms, textiles, daggers, chests, bowls, ladles, pipes, and halibut hooks, produced in the last two centuries by the Indians of the Northwest Coast, were featured in this exhibition of 100 objects drawn from the collections of the American Museum of Natural History.  A fully illustrated catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Marks of Achievement: Four Centuries of American Presentation Silver
exhibition_description: This exhibition, organized by The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, consisted of 150 exquisitely crafted pieces of American silver, dating from Colonial times to the present.  These objects were created as presentation gifts for individuals or institutions in recognition of outstanding achievement or to mark special occasions.

exhibition_title: Japanese Women Artists, 1600-1990
Japanese Women Artists, 1600-1990
Ansel Adams and Berenice Abbott
exhibition_description: This exhibition presented recent gifts to the Institute of work by the popular American photographers Ansel Adams and Berenice Abbott.  Adams (1902-1984) is revered for his grandiose photographs of the American West, and many of his well-known images from Yosemite National Park and the California wilderness were included.  Abbott's major body of work documented the drama of New York City, which will was well represented in the exhibition.  Approximately 60 large-scale prints which made up the exhibition, spanned each artist's most significant period of activity, from approximately 1930 through the 1970's.

exhibition_title: Nikuhitsu ukiyo-e meihin ten: Azabu bijutsukan shozo/Ukiyo-e Painting Masterpieces in the Collection of the Azabu Museum of Art
Nikuhitsu ukiyo-e meihin ten: Azabu bijutsukan shozo/Ukiyo-e Painting Masterpieces in the Collection of the Azabu Museum of Art

Bright Color, Bold Ink: Diversity in Momoyama Art
Islamic Art from the Permanent Collection
exhibition_description: Persian manuscript pages and calligraphy sheets, Moghul miniature paintings, Middle Eastern ceramics, glassware, metalwork, woodwork, and textiles were included in this exhibition of classic Middle Eastern art, organized by the Institute from its collections.

exhibition_title: Recent Accessions: Prints and Drawings
exhibition_description: During the 1980's, the museum's permanent collection was enriched by the addition of more than 500 prints, drawings, and illustrated books.  This exhibition focused on 100 of these recent accessions created between 1800 and 1975.  Highlights included important lithographs by Manet, Redon, Catlin, Whistler, Diebenkorn, and DeKooning, outstanding drawings by Girodet, Bonvin, and Hopper, and illustrated books by Picasso, Matisse and Dubuffet.

exhibition_title: Impressions of a New Civilization: The Lincoln Kirstein Collection of Japanese Prints 1860-1912
exhibition_description: This exhibition included 60 color woodblock prints created over a period of about 50 years, from 1860-1912.  The prints told the story of Japan's first foreign visitors, who settled in Yokohama, and of the amazing efforts for social change that followed the restoration of imperial rule in 1868.

exhibition_title: Tropism: Thirty Years of Photographs by Ralph Gibson
exhibition_description: This exhibition, organized by the International Center of Photography, was the first comprehensive survey of Ralph Gibson's entire 30-year career.  Gibson's works have been widely published in this country as well as in Europe and Asia.  Images included early photographs--many of which had never been exhibited--published and unpublished works, and color photography.

exhibition_title: New Works on Paper: Recent Accessions
exhibition_description: This exhibition included approximately 75 works of art on paper by contemporary artists.  All of the pieces in the exhibition were acquired by the museum between 1986 and 1988.  Featured among the drawings, prints, and artists' books were works by John Newman, Susan Rothenberg, and Francesco Clemente.  Working drawings and trial proofs for recently published editions from Vermillion Editions Ltd. were drawn from the Institute's own Vermillion archive to be included in this exhibition.

exhibition_title: The Essential Thread: Tapestry on Wall and Body
exhibition_description: Tapestry was the focus of this second exhibition in a series devoted to textile techniques.  Drawn from the museum's permanent collection, the tapestries illustrated the diversity of this weaving technique which has been used through the centuries to create objects ranging from clothing to home furnishings to purely decorative designs.  The exhibition included Coptic curtains, Chinese court robes, throne cushions, an ancient Peruvian fragment, Indian shawls, Arabian caftans, Russian religious vestments, Saltillo serapes, Middle Eastern kilims, Navajo rugs, and European wall hangings.

exhibition_title: A Matter of Style
exhibition_description: This exhibition illustrated two concepts: that style is an organizing principle applicable to all the arts; and that stylistic analysis is a tool with which both connoisseurs and museum visitors make sense of an encyclopedic collection.  Within the exhibition, comprised of 40 works of art from the permanent collection, there were opportunities for visitors to order and evaluate works of art, thereby developing their own powers of discrimination.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions in the Period Rooms
exhibition_description: In observance of an annual tradition, the Institute's Period Rooms were decorated as they would have been during the Christmas holidays of the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries.

exhibition_title: The Meiji Transformation: Change and Continuity in the Arts
exhibition_description: This exhibition of approximately sixty works drawn primarily from local collections, presented objects produced during the era of Japan's modernization.  Included in the exhibition were decorative arts, paintings, and prints, many of which reflected Japan's response to naturalism.

exhibition_title: The Collected and the Unexpected
exhibition_description: This exhibition explored regional collections created by people whose fascination with objects great and small shows creative, aesthetic sensibility and originality.  It examined the concept of the collector as artist and the collection as a work of art.

exhibition_title: Lyrical Documents: The Photographs of Robert Gene Wilcox
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured 75 works by one of Minnesota's most celebrated photographers, Gene Wilcox (1925-1970).  His images, whether of Canadian Indians, European villagers, or the hobos of Minneapolis, portray their subjects in a humanizing light that captures the simple dignity of their lives.  The Institute's collection of Wilcox material was acquired from the photographer's widow and forms the only such archive of his negatives and photographs.  A catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Ferreri, Mead and Murakami
exhibition_description: This exhibition by Minnesota artists included drawings by Lou Ferreri and paintings by Stuart Mead and Jean Murakami.

exhibition_title: Spirit House
exhibition_description: This multi-media installation by Seitu Jones, Ta-Coumba Aiken, and William Slack, explored the spiritual and aesthetic connections of African and African-American visual traditions.  Incorporating African objects from the museum's permanent collection, the artists created new installation contexts and aesthetic responses to the objects especially selected for this exhibition.

exhibition_title: Painting with Words: Calligraphy of Donald Jackson, Scribe to Elizabeth II, Queen of England
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured approximately 40 documents and books produced by calligrapher Donald Jackson.  Included in the exhibition were pieces done for the English House of Lords and the Royal Family, as well as works of art created by Jackson.

exhibition_title: World Art Project
exhibition_description: This project by artist Stan Shetka involved the contribution of items by the public.  The gallery installation was dependent on Shetka's international collection system through mailings, newspaper, television, international telephone lines and a computerized call-in information center.  The exhibition evolved daily as Shetka directed and defined the project.

exhibition_title: 2-D on 3-D
exhibition_description: This exhibition was comprised of works by 29 artists from throughout the state.  All of the artists in the exhibition combined two-dimensional and three-dimensional media for creating their pieces.  This exhibition was conceived and organized by Curt Hoard and David Feinberg, artists and colleagues at the University of Minnesota.

exhibition_title: Norwegian Folk Art: The Migration of a Tradition
First Fire: Richard Bresnahan and New Pottery from St. John's
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured potter Richard Bresnahan and the remarkable results obtained from the first firing of a new wood-burning kiln on the campus of St. John's University, St. Cloud, Minnesota.  Bresnahan, who apprenticed with the Japanese Nakazato family of potters, well known for his skillfully thrown, uniquely-glazed ceramics and for his commitment to the environment -- used materials indigenous to Minnesota and stoked his kiln with waste wood gathered from the forests surrounding St. John's.  The successful firing of the enormous 1,200 cubic feet, three-chamber kiln marked a high point in Bresnahan's artistic career.  In addition to the subtle hues of natural ash glazes, the final chamber of the kiln also yielded unglazed ceramics with flash marks of bright reds and oranges, and contrasting soft tans and browns.  This exhibition included 50-60 of these objects, and included large-scale storage jars, vases, platters, and teabowls.
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

exhibition_title: The Twin Cities on Paper: A Century of Architectural Drawings for Minneapolis and Saint Paul
exhibition_description:
Organized by The Minneapolis Institute of Arts in honor of the American Institute of Architects’ annual meeting in Minneapolis in May, this exhibition looked at local buildings from the perspective of their drawings and models.  Dating from 1880s to the 1900s, these works were arranged typologically, beginning with museum, followed by other buildings in the public realm such as churches, hotels, libraries, and office buildings and concluding with domestic architecture for both town and country.  
The majority of the drawings came from the impressive holdings of the Northwest Architectural Archives, University of Minnesota Libraries, St. Paul; in addition, Avery Library, Columbia University, New York, and the Heinz Architectural Center at The Carnegie Museum of Art, Pittsburgh, lent less familiar works which created a more comprehensive architectural representation of the Twin Cities.
Architect highlighted in the exhibition included Edwin Lundie, well known locally for his residential architecture of the 1920s and 1930s; Harvey Ellis, gifted draughtsman for LeRoy Buffington around 1890 and who later designed furniture for Gustav Stickley; William Channing Whitney, designer of homes for many prominent Minnesotans at the turn of the century, and John Howe, a highly talented draughtsman for Frank Lloyd Wright.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions in the Period Rooms
The Art of Construction: Elements of Architectural Design
Staffs of Life: Rods, Staffs, Scepters, and Wands from the Coudron Collection of African Art
exhibition_description: This exhibition was composed of staffs, scepters, and other prestigious objects from West and Central Africa, drawn from a highly significant private collection.  Although linked by their unusual form, the objects in the exhibition showed an astonishing variety of sculptural form and decoration, ranging from studies of the human figure to extreme abstraction.  The exhibition was accompanied by a catalogue of the entire collection.
exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas

exhibition_title: Kitchen: Liza Lou
exhibition_description: "Kitchen" was a 150 square foot beaded environment of incredible detail.  A grocery list hung from the refrigerator door, blue beads flowed from the sink spigot over a pile of dishes and a beaded cherry pie sat in the oven.  The installation centered on the role of women in history and their labor-intensive work in the room where so many women have spent decades of their lives.  The artist glorified the drudgery of domestic work and in so doing created a space for critical reflection about the role of women in the home and what is traditionally seen as "women's work."

This exhibition featured artist, Michael Rathbun, whose solo voyage across Lake Michigan in a twelve-foot sailboat of his own construction inspired this recent installation work and wooden sculpture of massive proportions.  Through his MAEP exhibition N44 57.488’ W9316.353’ (the longitued and latitude coordinates which pinpoint his exhibition’s exact position on earth), Rathbun built a monumental wooden sculpture that speculated on a future journey - one he hopes to take with his two brothers across the Pacific Ocean in search of a blue whale.

exhibition_title: Poetic Horizons: The Landscape Tradition in Britain, 1750-1850
exhibition_description:
The century between 1750 and 1850 , often referred to as the "golden age" of British landscape art, when the genre reached perhaps its highest level of achievement and recognition.  This exhibition was designed to survey the work of the leading British landscape artists of the period, with a special emphasis on watercolors and prints. The exhibition featured more than 180 prints, drawings, watercolors and paintings drawn from the Institute's permanent collection and other institutional and private collections.  A selection of prints and preparatory drawings from Turner's landmark publication Liber Studiorum, was highlighted.  A technical display and a selection of English decorative arts was also shown.
An illustrated catalogue was produced by The Minneapolis Institute of Arts.

exhibition_title: George Earl Resler: Minnesota Etcher
exhibition_description: This exhibition presented a retrospective of the work of St. Paul artist George Resler (1882-1954).  It included a selection of etchings, drypoints, and drawings of Resler's preferred subject of landscape as well as portraits of family and friends.  Many of his landscapes featured Minnesota scenes and St. Paul in particular.  Resler was inspired by the painter-etchers of the 19th century such as James McNeill Whistler, Seymour Haden and Alphonse Legros.  This exhibition reintroduced the artist to the general public and marks the first time the Institute exhibited the works of George Resler. A publication accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: The Color Red: Messages in Textile Art
exhibition_description: An Asian bride, a Spanish bull fighter and Santa Claus all use red cloth to celebrate.  Created from the museum's permanent collection, this exhibition exposed the diverse cultural preferences and meaning of this single color.  Also considered were the many ways to create the color red.

exhibition_title: Reading and Collecting Books
exhibition_description: This exhibition included approximately 50 of the rarest, most beautiful books in Twin Cities' private collections and public institutions.  The entire book community was involved and the goal of the exhibition was to promote interest in book collecting in Minnesota.

exhibition_title: riverheart
exhibition_description: This installation featured photographer/installation artist Linda Rossi who combined illuminated sculpture, video, sound, and still photography in a "room of the seasons."  Rossi used images of the environment (still work and footage from Minnesota and Africa) and the human body in multi-referential narratives that explored personal, cultural, and geographic territories.

exhibition_title: Henri Cartier-Bresson: Pen, Brush, and Cameras
exhibition_description: This was a major retrospective exhibition that explored the career of Henri Cartier-Bresson, one of the leading photo-journalists of twentieth-century photography.  The exhibition was comprised of nearly 100 drawings and photographs selected by the artist, included for the first time a representative sampling of eight rarely exhibition oil paintings and seven films by or about the artist.  The exhibition toured selected museum during 1996 and 1997.  A small illustrated catalogue accompanied the exhibition and included an essay by a leading Cartier-Bresson scholar.

exhibition_title: Jean Puiforcat's Coffee and Tea Service and the Art Deco Style
exhibition_description: This exhibition focused on a recent acquisition of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts, a rare and important silver Art Deco coffee and tea service by French silversmith Jean Puiforcat.  The exhibition discussed the service in the context of the work of Jean Puiforcat and the Art Deco style in Europe and America.

News from a Radiant Future: Soviet Porcelain from the Collection of Craig H. and Kay A. Tuber
exhibition_description: This exhibition consisted of Soviet propaganda porcelain made during the first decade after the Russian Revolution, and featured three groups of designs: styles adapted from imperial porcelain of the old regime, non-traditional styles depicting abstract shapes and Constructivist imagery, and decorations inspired by Russian legends and village life.  Included were forty-three plates and other porcelain objects produced by artists at the State Porcelain Factory in Petrograd (now St. Petersburg) between 1918 and 1927.

exhibition_title: Truths and Trials: Color Photography Since 1975
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured about 50 color photographs made over the last twenty years, all selected from the Institute's permanent collection.  Two basic instincts informed color work during this period: truthful representations of reality and experimental expressions of creativity.  Photographers such as Harry Callahan, Frank Gohlke, and Barbara Karant present common, recognizable subjects in a seemingly objective and straightforward manner.  In contrast, others, like Robert Heinecken, James Henkel, and Joan Lyons, question normal camera vision by manipulating their images and combining different media.  The wide range of work that comes out of both camps testified to the vital state of recent color photography.

exhibition_title: Ancient Nubia: Egypt's Rival in Africa
exhibition_description: Drawing on The University Museum’s extensive Nubian collection of over 7,000 pieces, and information from Museum-sponsored expeditions to the area, this exhibition provided an exciting look at the history of Nubian culture.  The show consisted of over 200 artifacts including pottery, jewelry, statuary, glass vessels, and metal implements, and traced the development of Nubian culture from circa 3,100 B. C. to A. D. 500.  An illustrated catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Art Works: The PaineWebber Collection of Contemporary Masters
exhibition_description:
The PaineWebber Collection offered a great opportunity to survey the major currents in the art of the past four decades.  The exhibition presented 70 important works of art, primarily paintings with a selection of sculpture, and drawings and prints.  Artists represented include Guston, Motherwell, de Kooning, Bourgeois, Rauschenberg, Warhol, Richter, Johns, Twombly, Kiefer, Salle, Schnabel, and Baldessari.
The exhibition was accompanied by a fully illustrated catalogue prepared by Monique Bendert and Jennifer Wells, and published by Rizzoli.

exhibition_title: Muertos de Gusto! Day of the Dead: Memory and Ritual
exhibition_description: The celebration of the Day of the Dead has its roots in Mexico's indigenous past.  When the Spanish brought Catholicism to Mexico it added other components to the traditional annual observance of Day of the Dead which is held on All Souls Day (November 2) in Mexico.  The ancient indigenous people of Mexico did not see death as and end but as part of a never ending cycle.  On Day of the Dead, people visit the graveyards of deceased family members and in homes, and makeshift altars are created and decorated with flowers and photos of the deceased loved ones.  The Mexican tradition is filled with both humor and sadness, and reminds all of us that no matter what our personal religious beliefs may be, life is precious and to be fully enjoyed.  This exhibition is the nation's largest on the subject, and combines both traditional and contemporary components of this intriguing holiday. Included are artists from Mexico, Chicago, and from other parts of the U.S.

exhibition_title: Seasonal Pleasures in Japanese Art, Part II
Dorothea Lange: American Photographs
exhibition_description: This exhibition was the first major retrospective of Lange’s work to look not only at her early documentary work during the Depression, but also her work documenting important wartime changes in California such as the relocation of Japanese-Americans and the operation of fast-growing war industries in Richmond, California. Approximately 90 - 100 photographs were exhibited, most of them vintage and many of which had never before been exhibited or published.  This was the first solo exhibition of Lange’s work to be seen at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts.  The exhibition was accompanied by an illustrated catalogue.

exhibition_title: A Garden of Delights: 19th-Century Botanical Prints
exhibition_description: Inspired by the recent choices of signature images for Art in Bloom, this exhibition utilized the Institute's impressive holdings of botanical illustrations from the Minnich Collection.  Works by Pierre-Joseph Redouté, "the Raphael of flowers," were highlighted.

exhibition_title: Seydou Keita: Photographs 1949-1959
exhibition_description: This exhibition comprised of 39 portraits, in the tradition of August Sander and Richard Avedon (his generous, complimentary mode), done in Bamako, Mali during the ten year period of 1949-1959.

exhibition_title: A Glove and Intermezzi: Max Klinger's Prints of Fantasy
exhibition_description: Painter, sculptor, and printmaker, the German artist Max Klinger is most revered for his extraordinary print cycles of fantastical, religious, and mythological subjects.  As an art student in Karlsruhe and Berlin in the 1870s, Klinger came to believe that only the graphic arts could express the extremes of fantasy and emotion, which were inappropriate to the more realistic arts of painting and sculpture.  The 14 print portfolios Klinger created between 1879 and 1915 were instrumental in reviving the art of etching and graphic arts in turn-of-the-century Germany.  The exhibition featured the portfolios, A Glove and Intermezzi, which date from 1881, yet anticipated the dream-like imagery and macabre themes of 20th-century surrealism.

exhibition_title: The Scholar's Study: Chinese Art in the Literati Tradition
exhibition_description: This exhibition included between 50 and 60 works of literati art dating from the 16th - 18th centuries drawn from the permanent collection.  The show focused on artistic themes, literature, and collecting tastes peculiar to the scholar -- painters of the Ming dynasty (1368-1655).  The works were divided into three categories: a) objects from the scholar's desk used in the production of painting and calligraphy, b) works of art produced by literati artists, and c) works of art collected by literati artists.

exhibition_title: The Women of the Pleasure Quarter: Japanese Paintings and Prints of the Floating World
The Women of the Pleasure Quarter: Japanese Paintings and Prints of the Floating World
Scouting with Norman Rockwell
exhibition_description: This exhibition was traveling to seventeen venues across the United States.  It was done in conjunction with a celebration of the Boy Scouts of America’s 85th anniversary and special recognition events at each site to thank important donors to their program.  The exhibit included sixteen paintings.

exhibition_title: Earth, Water, Air, Fire
exhibition_description:
Earth, water, air, and fire have inspired artistic works since ancient times.  A creative relationship with these four elements can deepen our understanding of life itself.  A four-part exhibition featured work by 63 Minnesota artists.  The 63 artists observed the world as they document its beauty, observed its specifics, portrayed its degradation, enshrined its power, presented its cultural confinement, examined the tradition of the landscape and contemplated a variety of metaphorical possibilities.  Each of the four exhibits -- earth, water, air, and fire -- presented diverse points of view and a wide range of media which included painting, drawing, photography, computer generated work, ceramic sculpture, mixed-media constructions, caste bronzes, site-specific installations, textiles, performance art, film, and video.
Dates for each exhibition were as follows:
Earth: May 31 - June 30, 1996
Water: July 12 - August 11, 1996
Air: August 23 - September 22, 1996
Fire: October 11 - November 17, 1996

exhibition_title: A Closer Look: Manet's "The Smoker"
exhibition_description: This installation explored Manet’s transformation of a single theme in different media, by comparing an oil painting, an etching, and a drypoint.

exhibition_title: A Closer Look: Rembrandt's "Goldweighter's Field"
exhibition_description: The etching and drypoint The Goldweigher’s Field is the boldest and most panoramic landscape print of Rembrandt van Rijn with its elongated horizontal format and blank sky.  The artist reduced the fields, the groups of trees and the houses in the landscape to almost abstract forms.  This new acquisition complemented a rare counterproof impression of this print which entered the Institute’s collection in 1916 as a gift of Herschel V. Jones.  The “Closer Look” exhibition will examine The Goldweigher’s Field in the context of eight of Rembrandt’s landscape prints from the permanent collection.

exhibition_title: Ceramic Tileworks of the Ming Dynasty
exhibition_description: This exhibition examined a category of ceramics commonly called "tileworks pottery" and the important role it played in the architecture, folklore and popular religions of traditional China.

exhibition_title: Anatomy of a Japanese Print
exhibition_description: This display encouraged visitors to explore a Japanese print for information artfully included in the design, including the title of the print, the series title, the artist's signature and seal, the censor's seals and other elements that could enrich our understanding of a print as a cultural artifact.

exhibition_title: Glimpse of Nature
Japanese Paintings: Figures in Japanese Style
Shana Kaplow / Shannon Kennedy
exhibition_description: An exhibition of paintings by Shana Kaplow and mixed-media photo constructions by Shannon Kennedy.

exhibition_title: Nature World
exhibition_description: “Nature World” featured the contemporary art of David Lefkowitz, who addresses our culture-conflicted perceptions of nature through a diverse body of work that merges traditions of western representational oil painting with objects and images from contemporary consumer culture.

exhibition_title: Theater of Machines
exhibition_description: An exhibition of collaborative work by Irve Dell and Brad Kaspari featured interactive and mechanical computer-controlled site-specific sculptural installations and objects that explore the shifting relationship between art and technology.

exhibition_title: Christopher Brown: Works on Paper
Holiday Traditions in the Period Rooms
From Mantegna to Raimondi: Italian Renaissance Prints from the Collection of Herschel V. Jones
exhibition_description: An installation of Old Master Italian engravings included masterpieces by Andrea Mantegna, Antonio Polaiuolo, Marcantonio Raimondi, Agostino Veneziano and Ugo da Carpi was the first of several new permanent collection galleries for works on paper.  The pieces were donated by Herschel V. Jones, the founder of the Department of Prints and Drawings.

exhibition_title: Landmarks in Print Collecting: Masterpieces from the British Museum
exhibition_description: This exhibition was the first exhibition of prints chosen entirely from the British Museum's holdings ever to come to the United States. It was composed of 100 outstanding examples spanning the history of Western printmaking from rare 15th century German woodcuts and early Italian engraving, through the masters of the Renaissance and Baroque periods, to the Impressionists, Expressionists and American etchings and lithographs of the 20th century. While multiple examples of such masters as Schongauer, Dürer and Rembrandt were included, some of the emphasis of the exhibition were on artists from the less widely-shown periods and fields, such as the 16th century etchers of the School of Fontainebleu. What distinguished this exhibition is its structure which examined ten significant groups of acquisitions made by gift or purchase during the history of the British Museum. The exhibition was accompanied by a fully-illustrated catalogue.

exhibition_title: Dale Chihuly: Installations 1964-1997
exhibition_description: Seattle-based Dale Chihuly, often referred to as the “Tiffany of contemporary glass,” is one of the most exciting, best-known, and technically demanding artists working in the medium of glass today.  Taking inspiration from the work of Venetian glass masters, and floral and sea forms, he created works that pushed the limits of the glass medium in all directions, including color, size, and display. Using these oversized works, Chihuly designed a dozen different installations specifically for The Minneapolis Institute of Arts for the exhibition Dale Chihuly: Installations 1964-1997.  Chihuly’s magical installations, placed in front of window walls and within darkened galleries, accentuated the extraordinary qualities of his glass creations.

exhibition_title: Frankenstude
The Tale of Genji: Splendor and Innovation in Edo Culture
When Our Ship Comes In: Chinese Export Porcelain from the Hodroff Collection
exhibition_description: This exhibition, which showcased the collection of Leo and Doris Hodroff of Minneapolis, is one of the finest collections of Chinese export porcelain ever assembled.  These pieces were made for export markets around the world and date from the end of the 16th century to the middle of the 19th century. The exhibition examined Chinese export art in light of a consumer-driven, European influenced market, illustrating how the tastes of consumers produced a synthesis of eastern and western decoration and form. The organization of the exhibition reflected the various functions of the objects, ranging from utilitarian to the purely decorative, and showed why these wares were produced and used.

exhibition_title: Henri Matisse: La revelation m'est venue de l'Orient
Objects of Desire: The Modern Still Life
James Ensor
The Oriental Mirage: visions of the east from Delacroix to Klee
Intimate Encounters: Love & Domesticity in 18th Century France
Pierre-Paul Prud'hon
Pietro da Cortona
Augustin Pajou
After the Photo-Secession: American Pictorial Photography, 1910-1955
exhibition_description: This exhibition examined the social and artistic development of pictorial photography between the World Wars. Approximately 150 photographs, characterized by their accessible subject matter, manipulative techniques, and beautiful imagery are included in the show and are by such artists as D.J. Ruzicka, Adolf Fassbender, A. Aubrey Bodine, Eleanor Parke Curtis, Frank Roy Fraprie, William Mortensen, P.H. Oelman, Harry K. Shigeta, and Max Thorek. This was the first major exhibition on this subject matter and travels to a number of American museums after its presentation in Minneapolis. A major publication accompanied this exhibition.

exhibition_title: After the Photo-Secession: American Pictorial Photography, 1910-1955

Approximately 150 photographs, characterized by their accessible subject matter, manipulative techniques, and beautiful imagery are included in the show and are by such artists as D.J. Ruzicka, Adolf Fassbender, A. Aubrey Bodine, Eleanor Parke Curtis, Frank Roy Fraprie, William Mortensen, P.H. Oelman, Harry K. Shigeta, and Max Thorek. This was the first major exhibition on this subject matter and travels to a number of American museums after its presentation in Minneapolis. A major publication accompanied this exhibition.

exhibition_title: After the Photo-Secession: American Pictorial Photography, 1910-1955
exhibition_description: This exhibition examined the social and artistic development of pictorial photography between the World Wars. Approximately 150 photographs, characterized by their accessible subject matter, manipulative techniques, and beautiful imagery are included in the show and are by such artists as D.J. Ruzicka, Adolf Fassbender, A. Aubrey Bodine, Eleanor Parke Curtis, Frank Roy Fraprie, William Mortensen, P.H. Oelman, Harry K. Shigeta, and Max Thorek. This was the first major exhibition on this subject matter and travels to a number of American museums after its presentation in Minneapolis. A major publication accompanied this exhibition.

exhibition_title: The Sevres Porcelain Manufactory
Exiles and Emigres: 1922-1945
Critiques of Pure Abstraction
Rosa Bonheur
The Poetics of Vision: Photographs from the Collection of Harry M. Drake
exhibition_description: This exhibition highlighted the strengths of Harry Drake's collection of about 250 photographs.  Fully half of the images are by Minor White, representing the most significant private collection of this important artist's work.  The exhibition examined Harry's personal eye as a collector and the varied artistry of the major twentieth-century photographers whose work he has acquired.  Seventy-five photographs by 25 photographers were included in the exhibition some of whom were Minor White, Paul Caponigro, Wynn Bullock, Brett Weston, Michael Kenna, David Teplica, Eikoh Hosoe and Josef Sudek.  A catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Mantras: Paintings of Repetition
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured large-scale “romantic minimalist” paintings by German-born artist Barbara Kreft, who has made the Upper Midwest her home for nearly two decades.  This region’s diverse landscape - its wide horizons and high arctic sky - has profoundly influenced her work.  Well known for her elegantly evocative paintings of magical plant-filled environments, Kreft had depicted mysterious light-filled spaces containing pods, seeds, and various floating organic forms that seem to reflect psychological states of being.  Her recent paintings speak to the luminous beauty of the earth.  They present natural phenomena and life pattern in simpler spaces that suggest constellations of various sorts.  The atmospheric and reductive quality of these large canvases heightened their contemplative effect and encouraged the viewer to linger in the artist’s ethereal landscape.

exhibition_title: Art and Insanity
Photography:  The Collection Grows, 1983 - 1996
New England Hearth and Home | A Passion for the Past: The Collection of Bertram K. and Nina Fletcher Little at Cogswell's Grant, and Inherited and Collected: The Arts of New England in Minnesota
exhibition_description: These complementary exhibitions explored Minnesota’s New England roots.  “A Passion for the Past” showcased a remarkable collection of folk and fine art, including paintings, drawings, furniture, textiles, and ceramics.  “Inherited and Collected” featured objects brought to Minnesota by early settlers and items collected today by Twin Citians.

exhibition_title: Color, Color, Who's Got the Color? Kaffe Fassett
exhibition_description: Highlighted in the exhibition were 136 works of the textile artist and colorist, Kaffe Fassett.  The exhibition was based on a retrospective held at the Victoria and Albert Museum, London.  Included were works ranging from the first piece knitted by the artist to needlepoint carpets, site installations and wall hangings.  The intricate patterns and lush colors of his knitted and needlework pieces illustrated Mr. Fassett’s use of nature and decorative objects for his design inspiration.

exhibition_title: Starburst Splendor:  Selections from the Minnesota Quilt Project
exhibition_description: The quilts included in this exhibition were drawn from the Minnesota Quilt Project, an organization that was founded in 1988 to document historic quilts and quilt makers in Minnesota.  The quilts in the exhibition featured the star motif, a design theme that includes many popular patterns and one that was particularly favored by Native American quilt makers.  All quilts were made in America, but were not limited to those made in Minnesota.  The length of the exhibition incorporated two rotations of twenty quilts each.

exhibition_title: Dyeing to Please: From Surface Application to Total Immersion
exhibition_description: This textile exhibition explored cultural aesthetic preferences in relation to styles of dye application and the technology behind it; its effect on economics, specialized labor, and international trade.  The textiles were from the permanent collection of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts.

exhibition_title: Reginald Sanders, March 6 - April 20, 1997
exhibition_description: An exhibition of kinesthetic abstraction and miniature collage work by 75 year old artist, writer, and musician, Reginald Sanders, explored the relationship between jazz and contemporary abstraction.

exhibition_title: Sir Henry Raeburn
Scandinavian Moderne
Scandinavian Moderne
From Where My Parents Came: Portraits from the Ukraine
exhibition_description: An exhibition of portraits by photographer Katherine Turczan explored the contemporary lives of women in the Ukraine, and examined the extraordinary changes of the post-Communist era.

exhibition_title: Masters of Light: Dutch Painters in Utrecht During the Golden Age
Masters of Light: Dutch Painters in Utrecht During the Golden Age
Masters of Light: Dutch Painters in Utrecht During the Golden Age
Founders and Heirs of the New York School
Founders and Heirs of the New York School
Founders and Heirs of the New York School
The Artful Animal: 500 Years of Beasts, Birds, and Other Earthly Creatures
exhibition_description: Drawn primarily from the MIA’s permanent collection, this inter-departmental exhibition examined the theme of the animal in art from the 16th century to the present. Approximately 80 prints, drawings, watercolors, paintings, sculptures, books, and decorative objects, which depict mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, insects, and imaginary creatures, were featured.

exhibition_title: Albrecht Dürer and the Prints of the Danube School
exhibition_description: This exhibition highlighted the artists of the Danube School who lived and worked by the Danube River from Regensburg to Vienna in the early 16th-century.  The prints of the Danube School are characterized by a profound sensitivity to nature.  Landscape and atmospheric elements were used to an unprecedented degree to emphasize subject and mood, while the structure of growing, organic things governed the compositions.  It was the Danube School which first introduced into Western Art the idea that pure landscape was a subject worthy of representation.  Artists highlighted in the exhibition included Albrecht Dürer, Albrecht Altdorfer, Lucas Cranach, and Augustin Hirchvogel.

exhibition_title: Lives Connected: Jacob Lawrence and Gwendolyn Knight, including “The Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman Series of Narrative Paintings by Jacob Lawrence”
exhibition_description: The artists Jacob Lawrence and Gwendolyn Knight met while working in Harlem in the 1930s; their friendship led to marriage in 1941, and their long relationship has been a vital factor in both artist’s work.  Jacob Lawrence’s series on Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman of 1938-40 told the story of these African-American heroes in over 60 sequential panels. While Jacob’s paintings told a story and relate to his cultural history, Gwendolyn’s paintings and prints were more personal and represent the people and experiences which have filled her life.

exhibition_title: Africa Rotation 1998
exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas

exhibition_title: The Indian Sari: Draping Bodies, Reveling Lives
Bob Thompson Retrospective
Splendid Morocco
Land Used
Exchange of Remington Sculptures
Relative Perfection
exhibition_description: An exhibition of new installations by Leigh Kane, Cynthia Morgan, and Barbra Nei shook up the formulaic world of conventional culture. These feminist works tempered a host of serious questions about contemporary expression, shedding light on the complexity of presentation and cultural documentation.

exhibition_title: Farewell to the Wet Nurse: Etienne Aubry and Images of Breast-Feading in Eighteenth Century France
Memory of the Hand: Making Sense of Art through Touch
exhibition_description: Featured in this exhibition were the works of Rosalyn Driscoll, who has created sculpture for those with limited or no vision.  Two to three of her sculptures, in addition to selections from The Minneapolis Institute of Arts’ permanent collection, were displayed to encourage museum audiences to think about the knowledge gained about art through the sense of touch.

exhibition_title: Morrison's Horizons
exhibition_description: The unique and abiding vision of critically acclaimed modernist, George Morrison, is honored in his 80th year through this special exhibition of recent paintings that extend his famous “Horizon Series.”  George Morrison (b. 1919) was the first and most prominent Native American artist on the New York art scene in the 1940s.  For five decades he has been recognized for a prolific career as an abstract painter and sculptor and is represented in museum, private, and corporate collections regionally, nationally, and internationally.  Morrison is seen as a prominent figure of the American Indian Fine Arts Movement.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions in the Period Rooms
100 Years of Gund Toys
exhibition_description: A small exhibition of Gund toys held in conjunction with the “Bear House” benefit sponsored by the Friends of the Institute.

exhibition_title: Ancient Gold: Jewelry from the Dallas Museum of Art
exhibition_description: The Dallas Museum of Art’s collection of Mediterranean gold represents a historically wide-ranging group of ancient work from the critical periods of Greek and Etruscan jewelry making and is one of the finest such collections in the United States.  105 objects ranging from exotic Etruscan fibula and earrings to a Greek olive wreath and medallions and a representation of Roman gold work, including a dramatic snake armlet, were featured.  The selection allows the viewer to understand the stylistic development during the 1,000 year period from the 7th-century BC to the 3rd-century AD and the importance of gold and the display of wealth was to these three cultures.
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

exhibition_title: Netsuke: The Japanese Art of Miniature Carving
exhibition_description: As demand for large scale Buddhist sculpture declined in seventeenth century Japan, the secular form of miniature sculpture, called netsuke, rose to prominence. Netsuke were an integral part of Japanese dress during the Edo period (1600-1868) and characterized the era's concepts of iki, a chic sense of stylishness and shadatsu, a sensible sort of Bohemianism. This exhibition explored the beginnings of netsuke production, major schools of netsuke carving, contemporary netsuke artists and major iconographic themes.
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

exhibition_title: Sovrane Passioni
Paul Gauguin: Das verlorene Paradies
Fotografs of Flowers
exhibition_description: This exhibition, which coincided with Art in Bloom, included about sixty photographs drawn from the permanent collection representing various uses of flowers. Classical photographers, such as Ansel Adams and Minor White, focused on flowers in natural settings like gardens and forests. Fashion and documentary photographers like Edward Steichen and James Van Der Zee incorporated flowers into their advertising, wedding, and funeral pictures. And high-art photographers, such as Charles Berg and Adolf de Meyer, included flowers in their exquisite nude and still life photographs. This selection presented work spanning over one hundred years, from Europe, Asia, and the United States, photographed in both black and white and color.

exhibition_title: Artisans in Silver: Judaica Today
exhibition_description: This exhibition was organized by the Society of American Silversmiths and was the first devoted exclusively to the presentation of contemporary hand-made Jewish ritual silver.  It featured fifty-four objects from 35 artisan members of SAS, and showcased objects in almost every style and silversmithing technique, many in combination with other materials.  The traveling exhibition esd expanded by including historical ceremonial objects from outside private collections and synagogues.

exhibition_title: Monet at Vétheuil: The Turning Point
exhibition_description:
During the a record-setting cold winter in 1880, Monet was forced to paint works of the elemental forces of nature that did not include any depiction of  the human figure. After this winter, such subjects of deserted landscapes with the forces of nature at work became his abiding subject.  This exhibition featured a group of paintings by Monet that examined the decisive moment of personal and artistic development during which the artist employed the concept of serial painting that was to dominate his later work.  The exhibition also explored the psychological aspects of Monet’s artistic evolution that may have factored into the artist’s decision to attempt a new mode of painting.
A 60 page catalogue accompanied this exhibition.

exhibition_title: Tokaido Road: Gus Foster and Ando Hiroshige
exhibition_description: In 1832 Ando Hiroshige traveled the Tokaido, the roadway linking the historic capital of Kyoto with Shogun’s court in Edo.  Based on sketches made along the way, Hiroshige later created one of the world’s most celebrated and artistically influential series of woodblock prints.  Nearly 160 years later, Gus Foster, an American panoramic landscape photographer, was determined to retrace Hiroshige’s footsteps.  His 360° photographs, taken while walking the entire 306 mile route, strikingly document Japan’s metamorphosis in the twentieth century.  This exhibition paired each artists’ conception of the fifty-three “stations” of the Tokaido, revealing not only radical changes in Japan’s topography, but also the vast differences between artists’ inspiration, materials and creative interpretation.

exhibition_title: Opening of the Asian Art Galleries
New York, New York: Photographs of the City
exhibition_description: From the earliest years of photography, New York City, its buildings, places, and people have been the subjects for virtually every photographer who has visited or merely passed through that unique metropolis.  The exhibition presented a selection from the permanent collection of nearly 100 photographs spanning much of this century.  Photographers represented included Alfred Steiglitz, Lewis Hine, Berenice Abbott, Weegee, Helen Levitt, Jerome Liebling, Lee Friedlander, Garry Winogrand, Robert Frank, and others.

exhibition_title: The Mechanics of Motion: Photographs by Eadweard Muybridge and Harold E. Edgerton
exhibition_description: Eadweard Muybridge and Harold Edgerton were American pioneers of stop-action photography.  Muybridge, working in the 1880s at the University of Pennsylvania, produced sequential images of humans and animals doing the mundane and the arcane.  Edgerton, working in the middle of this century at MIT, experimented with early flash technology to freeze spectacular moments like a bullet shattering a light bulb.  The exhibition included about 75 photographs (divided equally between the two), all drawn from the MIA’s permanent collection.

exhibition_title: Isn't S/He A Doll? Play and Ritual in African Sculpture
exhibition_description: This exhibition examined the rich variety of forms and functions that characterize African conceptions of what the Western world calls “dolls” with 212 sculptures from 24 African countries. This was the first exhibition of its type. The primary goal of the exhibition was to explore questions about the definition and meaning of African dolls, allowing the visitor to contemplate dolls visually and functionally, challenging American notions of dolls as simple playthings.

exhibition_title: Common Objects/Obsessive Forms
exhibition_description: An exhibition of dynamic new work by sculptors Jan Elftmann, Bill Klaila, Joy Kops, Rollin Marquette, Rick Salafia, and Alan Wadzinski, included fantastic interactive sculpture: a cork bowling alley by Elftmann (the famous cork-car lady); a “virtual cave” by Klaila; and, a fleet of power window chairs by Kops.

From Post-War to Post-Modern: Interior Textiles, 1946-1976
Body Work: Photographs of Nudes
exhibition_description: This exhibition, drawn primarily from the Institute’s permanent collection, featured the work of about ten internationally known photographers. Their pictures spanned over one hundred years and represented every major movement in photography. Eadweard Muybridge, working in the late 19th-century, included nude men and women extensive analysis of human motion. Edward Steichen, as a turn-of-the-century pictorialist, idealized the nude, making evocative, soft-focus images. And Edward Weston, working after World War I, created modernist images of women, often emphasizing abstract shapes and forms. During the second half of the 20th-century, photographers such as Bill Brandt and July Coleman, continued to engage the human figure in a wide range of imagery, making it one of the medium’s most enduring subjects.

exhibition_title: Quality Control
exhibition_description: An exhibition of paintings, prints, mixed media and installation work by Ruthann Godollei, Alexa Horochowski, Lee Anne Swanson and Carolyn Swiszcz, four artists known for material innovation and narrative irony. Ruthann Godollei decoded patterns of family and social dysfunction in sparse, scratchboard drawings and monoprints depicting text and simple domestic objects. Alexa Horochowski scrutinized that behemoth institution known as marriage in a multi-sensory laundry room equipped with bubbles, a working ringer washer, and clothes line installed with embroidered underwear. Lee Anne Swanson combined hi-tech materials and lo-tech ideas in an installation that accessorized a huge, moody painting with a line of waist-high livestock tanks containing splashing glitter-covered mechanical duck decoys. Carolyn Swiszcz revealed her love for accidental gesture and material flexibility in a giant eraser board mandala.

exhibition_title: Arnold Newman Portraits
exhibition_description: Arnold Newman is one of the best-known and most distinguished portrait photographers of the 20th century. He pioneered “environmental portraiture,” a style that places the subject in a carefully composed setting that captures the essence of their work and personality. Since the 1930s, Newman has used his impeccable technique and innovative strategies to photograph many of the most accomplished people of the century – artists, writers, actors, composers, politicians and others – for publications such as Life, Holiday, Fortune and The New Yorker.

exhibition_title: John Howe in Minnesota: The Prairie School Legacy of Frank Lloyd Wright
exhibition_description: John (Jack) Howe was Frank Lloyd Wright’s talented chief draftsman from 1935 until Wright’s death in 1959. One of the first members of Wright’s Taliesin Fellowship, which was begun in 1932, Howe was schooled in the principles of organic architecture. In Wright’s studio, he directed the activities of the drafting room and completed many of Wright’s presentation drawings. Howe moved to Minnesota in the mid-1960s, where he ran his own architectural practice that focused, like Wright’s, on domestic architecture. This exhibition was comprised of 75 to 100 drawings mainly from the collections of the Northwest Architectural Archives, and the University Libraries, University of Minnesota. The exhibition coincides with the Frank Lloyd Wright Conservancy’s Annual Meeting, to be held September 20 – 24, 2000 in Minneapolis.

exhibition_title: Hair Stories
exhibition_description: This exhibition and event series presented the work of four visual artists, three writers, and one art historian to explore the personal, cultural, and mythological significance of hair. “Hair Stories” featured visual and verbal texts dealing with body-related issues: mixed media work by Diane Katsiaficas, paintings by Nancy Robinson, mixed media work and handmade paper by Erica Spitzer Rasmussen, and a video installation by Mara Zoltners; text and readings by Paulette Alden Bates, Valerie Miner, and Mary François Rockcastle; and a curated presentation of hair weavings from private Minnesota collections by Michael Stoughton, who will also contribute an essay on the historical use of hair in art and ornament. And because everyone has personal associations with hair, the gallery design provided opportunities for museum visitors to contribute to a collaborative work.

exhibition_title: American Impressionism: Treasures from the Smithsonian American Art Museum
exhibition_description: This exhibition presented the best works by artists influenced by the light and color of European Impressionism.  Led by the example of James McNeill Whistler, a generation of Americans studied abroad to absorb the new palette and compositions that were modernizing painting. Landscapes, figure and still life paintings, by Childe Hassam John Twachtman, Thomas Dewing, Maria Oakey Dewing, William Merrit Chase, and Theodore Robinson, marked a distinct departure from academic styles. In Boston, Edmund Tarbell, Frank Benson, Robert Reid, and Frederick Carl Frieseke developed a genteel version of Impressionism related to the culture of that city.  Landscapes and cityscapes by such artists as Daniel Garber and Maurice Prendergast carried Impressionism further into modernism by creating a new tapestry-like effect in their canvases. Taken together, these Impressionists foretold a new internationalism and modern view of life as America approached the twentieth century.

exhibition_title: Toys for Tea
An Acre of Art
exhibition_description: An Acre of Art reflected the focused engagement of artists Mark Knierim and Robert Lawrence with one acre of rural land which they will visit, research and experience for one year. Their process/performance culminated in an exhibition held in three locations: MAEP’s gallery at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts; the World Wide Web; and on the land itself. An Acre of Art extended the work of Knierim and Lawrence, both of whom are known for sculpture and site specific installations that deal with the cultural and physical aspects of place.

exhibition_title: The Art of 20th-Century Zen: Paintings & Calligraphy by Japanese Masters
exhibition_description: This exhibition included more than seventy paintings and calligraphies created by fourteen Japanese Zen Masters (thirteen monks and one nun) considered among the most important Zen artists and teachers of the modern era.  Among those included were Nakahara Nantenbo (Toju Zenchu, 1839-1925), Deiryu Kutsu (Kanshu Sojun, 1895-1954), Takeda Mokurai (1854-1930), Yamamoto Gempo (1866-1961), and the present abbot of Tofukuji temple, Fukushima Keido (born 1933). This was the first exhibition in the United States devoted to twentieth-century Zen paintings and calligraphy from Japan.  The exhibition was accompanied by a fully illustrated, color catalogue published Shambahala Publications.
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions in the Period Rooms
Star Wars: The Magic of Myth
exhibition_description: This exhibition showcased original artwork, props, models, costumes and characters used to create the “Star Wars” trilogy.  These artifacts are presented from the 1997 film “Star Wars: A New Hope,” through “The Empire Strikes Back” (1980), to “Return of the Jedi” (1983).

exhibition_title: Master Drawings from the Collection of Alfred Moir
exhibition_description: Alfred Moir, a retired art history professor and native Minnesotan, assembled an impressive private collection of mainly old master Italian drawings. There were also several French, Dutch and Spanish works and 19th-century drawings. His research over the years has yielded new attributions and expands our knowledge of artists working in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries. The exhibition was comprised of 75 drawings that included: black and colored chalks; pen and ink; brush and ink work and watercolor.

His research over the years has yielded new attributions and expands our knowledge of artists working in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries. exhibition_title: Night
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured nightscapes by photographer Chris Faust and painter Mike Lynch, artists who for many years have produced work that reveals the essence of the urban landscape. Diligent explorers of the physical worlds they are both drawn to places that seem to stretch over time – empty dock yards, railroad yards, industrial sites, architectural landmarks, and myriad nighttime haunts. Chris Faust is well known for panoramic black-and-white photographs of landscape, images often filled with contradiction and the enduring tension between humans and nature. A disciplined and masterly technician, Faust achieves lush tonal quality through a process called compensation development, which hear leaned from John Sexton, a student of Ansel Adams. Mike Lynch has been recognized for decades as an artist whose oil paintings, watercolors, and drawings display rare economy and sensitivity. He has devoted himself to night scenes since 1953, when he began painting in earnest. Lynch creates his evocative work through the use of time-honored practices such as nineteenth-century British watercolor techniques.

exhibition_title: China: Fifty Years inside the People's Republic
exhibition_description: This exhibition included some of the most significant images made in China by both Asian and Western photographers since 1949 and will present a compelling view of cultural, political and everyday life through the perspective of great photographers of the era. Their insights on a country virtually closed to the West for more than half of its existence evoke a magnificent land and its people, and an extraordinary time in history. The exhibition captured the uniquely complex and passionate attachments that bind both the native-born and foreign artist to China for a lifetime. A fully illustrated catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Reflections of a New Era: Modernist Metalwork 1880-1940
Symbols of Faith and Belief: Art of the Native American Church
exhibition_description: In the late 1870s a new religion based on the ritual consumption of the peyote cactus emerged on the North American Great Plains. The new religion intertwined traditional Native American beliefs with Christianity and spawned a new artistic tradition. This exhibition explored the ways the Native American Church has helped Native peoples in developing and preserving their identity while assisting in their adjustment to new social, cultural and economic circumstances. A wide range of artistic techniques and media evolved throughout the history of this religion to produce a distinctive genre of Native American art. The traditional expressive forms of beadwork, carving, metal smithing and feather work were combined to produce exquisite fans, rattles, drumsticks, jewelry, ritual staffs and other ceremonial objects used during the services of the Church. An understanding of the emergence of forms provides insight into the changing nature of American Indian life and art during the 20th-century.

exhibition_title: The Foot in the Door Show
exhibition_description: The original Foot in the Door Show, conceived by the Minnesota Artists Exhibition Program’s 1980 Artist Panel, was an open invitation to all artists of the state to participate in an exhibition at the Institute, provided they restricted the size of their artworks to one cubic foot of gallery space. In 1980, 740 artists submitted work for installation.  MAEP’s 1989-90 Artist Panel determined that this unusual exhibition format still served to acknowledge the vast amount of creative work being done in the state and staged a second show, ten years after the first. In 1990, 882 artists participated in the project.  Today, nearly two decades after the original “Foot”, the MAEP is still fundamentally and creatively committed to the democratic process.  And, the Artist Panel is still intrigued with this massive exhibition that forms itself entirely in the absence of curatorial judgment. Ultimately, The Foot in the Door 2000 celebrated the incredible diversity of vision that has evolved within Minnesota’s artist community.

exhibition_title: Masterpieces of Japanese Art from the Mary Griggs Burke Collection

Kofushiwaki Tsukasa
Nanga Special Exhibition
Metamorphosis to Freedom
exhibition_description: This installation of fourteen paintings and prose by Dr. Robert O. Fisch was a narrative of his personal journey from suppression to freedom.

exhibition_title: Sumptuous and Sublime: Two Japanese Rooms
exhibition_description: In October 2001, The Minneapolis Institute of Arts unveiled two Japanese period rooms: a formal audience hall (shoin) and a tea house (chashitsu). Both structures are highly visible installations within the permanent galleries of Japanese art and will serve to heighten awareness of the relationship between Japanese art and architecture. The rooms also address divergent aesthetic trends that arose during the sixteenth century in Japan: one that reflected the flamboyant tastes of Japan's warrior rulers, and the other that suggests the tea masters' admiration for the humble, simple and rustic.

exhibition_title: Wood Turning in North America Since 1930
exhibition_description: This exhibition, organized by Yale University Art Gallery, featured approximately 125 objects of turned wood including pieces from institutional and private collections. Because of the Industrial Revolution, the art of wood turning only started to be revived in America in the 1930s through the impetus of James Prestini (represented in the MIA collection). Following WWII, interest in pure design and the influences of Scandinavia inspired the likes of Bob Stocksdale and Philip Moulthrop. Their successors have pushed the limits of the medium ever since. The more experimental and challenging approach to wood turning between the 1960s and the 1990s was the main focus of this exhibition.

exhibition_title: Typography of Another Type: the Modernist Typewriter, 1890 - 1970
exhibition_description: To underline the importance of the typewriter in the development of typography, an adjacent installation of modernist typewriters, the first in a continuing design series of “case studies,” complemented the exhibition of modernist typography. Comprised of fourteen examples, it traces the evolution of typewriter design from 1890 to 1970. While focusing principally on physical design, function, styling and overall aesthetics, the implications for the appreciation of typography cannot be ignored, especially today with the advent of computerized desktop publishing.

exhibition_title: Reflections of Reality: Masterworks from the Lee Institute Collection
The Triumph of Maximilian I
Three Weavers: The Evolution of a Style
exhibition_description: This exhibition looks at the work of three artists, Morgan Clifford, W. Logan Fry and Laura Foster Nicholson. These contemporary weavers have chosen traditional techniques to visually express the ideas and concerns that capture their imagination.

exhibition_title: Conflict or Compromise? The Art of Collaboration
exhibition_description: Through the use of drawings, photographs and production samples, this exhibition presents a unique view of artist Laura Foster Nicholson’s collaborative work with the Jack Lenor Larsen Design Studio. Working over a two-year period, artist and designer combine their visions to create one of Larsen’s newest fabrics, Mythology.

exhibition_title: Recent Accessions
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured a selection of some of the MIA’s most notable recent acquisitions.

exhibition_title: Letter Perfect: The Art of Modernist Typography, 1896-1953
exhibition_description: This exhibition documented an important episode of typographic design through the collection of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts. It traced the progression of innovative letterforms from the turn of the 20th century to the 1950s, roughly a sixty-year period in which typography reflected the tremendous upheaval generated by the avant-garde in all the arts. Those advances made in a series of modernist movements, from Arts and Crafts, Art Nouveau, Dadaism, De Stijl, and Russian Constructivism through the Bauhaus, were graphically captured.

exhibition_title: Total Study Center
exhibition_description: For over fifteen years Bruce Tapola has carried on a line of inquiry about how artwork gets displayed, consumed, and digested. His elaborate site-specific installations part company with “museum-style” formats that present art as discrete of isolated objects. For “Total Study Center,” Tapola fused library, research facility, and conference room into a context with an “official” feel, suggesting that his artworks, like scientific diagrams and mathematical formulas, have concrete meaning. “Total Study Center” featured Tapola’s notebooks and stacks of drawings, so that people can handle them. The texts and notebooks cross-referenced diagrammatic art components hung on the walls so that meaning accumulates between images, objects, and the overall context.

exhibition_title: Views of the Mississippi
Blown Out of Proportion: A Survey of Studio Glass
exhibition_description: The first display of glass in the Institute’s Contemporary Ceramics and Glass Gallery, this installation featured 10-15 works of studio glass, beginning with examples by pioneering personalities in the movement from the 1950s-1970s, and following through with the work of contemporary designers. These American and international glass objects were drawn from the Institute as well as from local collections.

exhibition_title: American Gothic (Saturday Night/Sunday Morning) and Homo domesticus
exhibition_description: A double exhibition featuring a new film and sculpture by Chris Larson and an installation by drawing-based artist Melissa Stang. Known for his giant wooden machines “that work in the minds of the viewer,” Chris Larson presented his second film project that uses his sculpture as a theatrical set. As creative director, actor, set designer, and builder, Larsen used poetic themes of Americana and vaudeville to extend his inquiry into metamorphosis, the sacred and profane, or what country western music calls, “Saturday Night/Sunday Morning. In her exhibit, Homo domesticus, Melissa Stang presented two new works. One, a monumental assembled painting that sought to reconcile the expectations she feels as a woman artist; the other, a domestic interior of a mysterious herpetologist filled with kitschy decorative art objects depicting reptiles and amphibians. A table set with three-legged frog patterned plates (all drawn by Stang) reminded us to heed nature’s warnings and pays homage to the humble creatures who have given their lives for “human progress.”

exhibition_title: The Industrial Design Aesthetic 1900-1950
exhibition_description: This exhibition brings together a selection of industrial designs dating roughly from 1900 to 1950 (all the result of collaborative efforts, in some instances the individual designer’s identity remains unknown). The selection is purposely devoted to “industrial strength” designs that challenge long-standing concepts of beauty and taste. These designers and manufacturers were attempting to free themselves of applied decoration – function being the driving force. Such advanced ideas as engineering, utility, aerodynamics, styling, streamlining and the exploration of new techniques and materials were shared concerns.

exhibition_title: Cultural Crosscurrents: Elizabeth Catlett and Francisco Mora
Wood Turning in North American Since 1930
"Turning" Over Time: Historic Seating Furniture
exhibition_description: To put “Wood Turning in North America Since 1930” in historical context, this exhibition displayed examples of seating furniture from the museum’s permanent collection and private collections.

exhibition_title: Elegy: A Tribute Performance by the Twin Cities Arts Community
Frontera Lake Street
exhibition_description: "Frontera Lake Street" was presented through the museum's artist-run curatorial department, the Minnesota Artists Exhibition Program (MAEP), and by "Grupo Soap del Corazon ("spanglish" for "soap of the heart"), a group of artists and cultural activists devoted to the promotion of "border" culture in Minnesota. Grupo Soap produces and presents an ongoing series of exhibitions and projects that acknowledge, in particular, the Latinization of Lake Street in Minneapolis, with its mercados, taquerias, tortillerias, Latin record stores, nightclubs, boot shops, and salons. The Frontera Six borrowed from Mexican popular culture, each assumed the persona of an imaginary professional wrestler. In creating their own pop-wrestler characters, each Frontera artist invented a distinct personality and stage name, complete with masks and costumes. These theatrical characters worked to advertise the exhibition as well as to reconcile and celebrate "high" and "low" art. The artwork featured in the gallery installation included tiny landscapes painted on corn, rice, and other seeds by Salvador Espejo Benitez, depicted scenes of Minnesota on one side, and of Mexico, on the other. Luis Fitch's mixed-media work illustrated the opportunities that have drawn Mexicans to Minnesota as well as the risks that they have taken to cross over. A Central American-style trinket cart by Alexa Horochowski was packed with saleable art miniatures including hand-painted surrogate wrestling figures of the Frontera artists themselves. Douglas Padilla's intense symbolist paintings referenced the North and the South, connecting the Mississippi with the desert. Chilean painter Marcela Rodriguez A. was inspired by her Latino students and the landscape of her homeland. Xavier Tavera's large-scale color photographs revealed Latinos as both visible and invisible.

exhibition_title: Antiques Show and Sale 2001
Danny Lyon: Photographs 1962-2000
exhibition_description: This was the first exhibition at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts of this internationally important documentary photographer whose work became part of the permanent collection in 1986.  In April, 2001 two portfolios featuring Lyon’s images from the Civil Rights Movement (1962 – 1964) and his 1965 project “Uptown” were added to the Institute’s permanent collection.

exhibition_title: Recent Accessions
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured a selection of some of the MIA’s most notable recent acquisitions.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions in the Period Rooms
In Situ
exhibition_description: The Minnesota Artists Exhibition Program (MAEP) presented "In Situ", which featured new paintings by contemporary artists Jil Evans, James Holmberg, and Cristi Rinklin, three artists engaged with the creative connections between their paintings and the spaces that they occupy. Named for the Latin phrase, in situ, which means, roughly, "in the original location," the exhibition presented Evan's pseudo-figurative works, suspended overhead, to suggest the ceiling of a Baroque interior; Holmberg' s large-scale minimalist canvases, accompanied by painted "details" of the larger works; and Rinklin' s lush, wonder-filled oval paintings, "framed" with paint placed directly onto the gallery wall. Through their collaborative planning and process, the In Situ" artists established the exhibit's site-specific considerations, including what paintings to execute, object placement, color and lighting, and gallery design. Their installation offered a progression of experiences designed to heighten perceptual awareness for the viewer, illuminating the relationship between abstraction and observation.

exhibition_title: Jack Lenor Larsen: The Company and the Cloth
exhibition_description: Using Jack Lenor Larsen fabrics, the exhibition looked at high-end textile manufacturing in the last half of the 20th-century, emphasizing its international character and close association to contemporary aesthetic preferences of western culture.  The focus centered on creative design and production, bringing attention to a variety of issues which affected the end product, including cottage production to high tech manufacturing, the availability of materials, tariff restrictions, trade wars, among others.  The Jack Lenor Larsen archive was formally given to the museum and the University of Minnesota in 1999.

A World of Art: Gifts for the New Millennium
exhibition_description: This exhibition included approximately 200 important gifts to the museum given by individuals and corporations or purchased by our curators over the past ten years. Each curatorial department was represented. The arrival of more than 60 contemporary works of art from Target’s corporate art collection, nearly 4,000 textiles from the Jack Lenor Larsen archive donated by Cowtan & Tout in 1999, 475 objects from the Norwest Modernism Collection donated by Wells Fargo in 1998, and the ongoing gifts of Asian art from Ruth and Bruce Dayton all contributed to this opportunity to view an encyclopedic collection of world art. This collection embodied remarkable depth and breadth, providing a solid launching point and establishing a high level of quality for the museum’s future.

exhibition_title: Painting the Dakota: Seth Eastman at Fort Snelling
A Studio of Her Own: Boston Women Artists 1870-1940
Masters of American Photography
Michael Mazur: A Print Retrospective
exhibition_description: This retrospective exhibition highlighted the graphic art produced by Michael Mazur between 1958 and 1998. It provided an overview of the themes Mazur has explored over the years and reveals the depth of his talent as a graphic artist.

exhibition_title: Present/On the Road to Bazzano
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured two groups of large-scale works by one of America’s leading contemporary photographers. The culmination of a six-year project photographing the olive orchards and sacred trees of Spoleto, Italy, it revealed JoAnn Verburg’s profound interest in the reciprocity between humans and nature. The exhibition addressed the interrelatedness of life cycles, agriculture, and commerce and the mystery of sacred landscape. The installation reflected a sensitivity to architecture, human scale, and implied and actual time— issues more often addressed by installation art, architecture, or theater than by conventional photography. Verburg saw the olive tree, a life form essential to Italian culture, as a powerful metaphor for exchange. She made a gift of these works in her presentation of living cultural icons that do much to stimulate our own wonder and our own relationships with place and with what is sacred in nature.

exhibition_title: Howard Ben Tré: Sculpting Space in the Public Realm
exhibition_description: This exhibition focused on the glass sculptor Howard Ben Tré’s public projects for plazas and streetscapes, which are an increasingly important part of his work. A major component of the exhibition was the project recently approved by Target Corporation for their new public plaza in downtown Minneapolis. Howard Ben Tré is a very important player in the studio glass movement that developed in the 1960s and 1970s in Providence, Rhode Island. He has produced sculptures in cast translucent glass, employing an industrial process and medium known to him from working in various trades as a young man. His pieces exhibited extreme control and symmetry, and resembled ancient archeological finds. The sculptures developed as freestanding works that combine totemic forms with light (transmitted and reflected) and water to create a transcendent experience that invites human interaction.
