Contemporary Art on Paper, 1990-2000
Rembrandt as Printmaker
exhibition_description: The present installation is a survey of Rembrandt's activities as a printmaker, with selected works from the Institute's holdings of 156 Rembrandt prints.

exhibition_title: The Nabis
exhibition_description: In 1889, a group of young artists banded together in Paris and called themselves the Nabis, from the Hebrew word for “prophets.” Included in this group were Pierre Bonnard, Edouard Vuillard, Paul Ranson, Paul Sérusier, Maurice Denis, Félix Vallotton, Ker-Xavier Roussel, and Aristide Maillol. They sought to integrate art with life and move beyond what they perceived as the limits of Impressionism. Although the Nabis were trained as painters, they applied their talents to decorative objects and home interiors, theater design and programs, book and magazine illustration, as well as posters and prints. This installation highlighted a selection of their graphic works culled from the permanent collection.

exhibition_title: Käthe Kollwitz: Prints with a Purpose
Berenice Abbott: An American Photographer
exhibition_description: Berenice Abbott (1898 – 1991) is recognized as a pre-eminent influence in American photography and was active from the late 1920s through the 1960s. Most well-known for her heroic, yet affectionate and elegiac photographs of New York City in the 1930s, she was also widely recognized for her very original and skillfully realized scientific photographs and for her portraits of notable artists and writers. This exhibition consisted of approximately 40 photographs drawn from the permanent collection and several prints from a local private collector.

exhibition_title: Photogravure: Photographs in Ink
exhibition_description: Photogravure is the most lavish process by which photographs are rendered in printer’s ink. Invented in the late nineteenth century, it has been used since then by creative photographers interested in the rich, continuous tones of this intaglio process. Alfred Stieglitz illustrated his landmark periodical “Camera Work” with photogravures by Frederick H. Evans, Gertrude Käsebier, and others intent upon proving the artistic value of photography. From 1907 to 1930 Edward Curtis used the process to produce his mammoth and unrivaled record, “The North American Indian.” Paul Strand’s most significant portfolio, sensitively depicting Mexican culture, was printed in photogravure. And contemporary photographers such as Carrie Mae Weems and Bernice Ficek-Swenson also warmly embrace the process. The exhibition featured about 75 photogravures, all from the permanent collection of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts.

exhibition_title: A Vision of Paris: Etchings of Charles Meryon
exhibition_description: The etchings of Charles Meryon (1821-1879) reveal a vision of Paris before the changes put into effect during the rule of Napoleon III's Second Empire. Meryon's prints capture the essence of the medieval sections of town that were being torn down to accommodate the wide boulevards and new parks and squares of the Emperor's master plan. Yet, Meryon's etchings are not simply exact renditions of vanishing structures, but a personal vision of a city he loved. This vision was darkened by a severe mental illness which eventually took the artist's life just as his etchings were receiving serious attention and favorable reviews. Meryon's legacy of beautifully executed etchings continues to fascinate viewers, and he is considered on of the most gifted printmakers of all time.

exhibition_title: Etchings by Jacques Callot
exhibition_description: Jacques Callot (1592-1635), a native of Nancy, in the Duchy of Lorraine, ranks among the most productive and influential printmakers of the 17th century. He produced a body of 1,400 etchings, which led to his international acclaim. His imagery includes traditional religious themes, panoramic landscapes, costume portraits and caricatures. He was an innovative technician.

exhibition_title: From Frankenthaler to Freud: Master Contemporary Prints from the Permanent Collection
exhibition_description: From its founding as the Institute's first curatorial department in 1916, the Department of Prints and Drawings has actively acquired outstanding examples of contemporary graphic art for its permanent collection. This exhibition features a selection of more than 50 prints, monotypes, and multiples by leading American and European artists of the second half of the 20th-century, including Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Helen Frankenthaler, Cy Twombly, Robert Motherwell, Chuck Close, Joan Mitchell, Jim Dine, Ed Ruscha, Joseph Beuys, David Hockney, Georg Baselitz, Susan Rothenberg, Yvonne Jacquette, Lucien Freud, Vija Celmins, Elizabeth Murray, Anselm Kiefer, Kiki Smith, Leslie Dill, Lorna Simpson and others.

exhibition_title: Old Master Prints from the Permanent Collection
exhibition_description: This exhibition contains approximately 25 masterpieces created before 1600 from the Department of Prints and Drawings. The majority of the works have been added to the collection since 1985 and showcase the beauty of European printmaking of the 15th and 16th centuries.

exhibition_title: A Japanese Legacy: Four Generations of Yoshida Family Artists
exhibition_description: This exhibition features oil paintings, watercolors and woodblock prints by nine artists from a single Japanese family spanning, four generations and over 100 years. The exhibition addresses the evolution of the popular Japanese print from the late 1800s to present; the adaptation of western styles—naturalism and abstraction—into Japanese styles, methods and aesthetics; and, the dynamics of the family tradition in its commercial, stylistic, and interpersonal dimensions. The Yoshida family is fascinating because of the longevity and breadth of the family’s artistic legacy, its high aesthetic standards, and its internationalism. Thus, this exhibition allows for multiple foci, including aesthetics, production, culture, politics, and personalities.
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

American Sublime: Epic Landscapes of our Nation 1820-1880
exhibition_description: The focus of the exhibition are the great American landscape painters of the mid-19th century, concentrating on the Hudson River School and their contemporaries, who first gave complete visual expression to the idea of America as a vast new world. They took to a logical conclusion many of the ideas about landscape that had preoccupied European artists in the 18th and 19th centuries, while retaining the special character of the country they were exploring: magnificent, dramatic and subtle, by turns. The exhibition will include approximately 80 oil paintings featuring works by Bierstadt, Church, Cole, and Cropsey, among others.

exhibition_title: Picasso: Prints in the 20th Century
exhibition_description: This exhibition brings together a selection of approximately 75 prints that trace the development of Pablo Picasso's printmaking activities from 1904 until 1970. The exhibition includes etchings, drypoints, lithographs, and color linoleum cuts that reflect nearly every aspect of this prolific artist's extraordinary career.

exhibition_title: Picasso: Prints in the 20th Century
exhibition_description: This exhibition brings together a selection of approximately 75 prints that trace the development of Pablo Picasso's printmaking activities from 1904 until 1970. The exhibition includes etchings, drypoints, lithographs, and color linoleum cuts that reflect nearly every aspect of this prolific artist's extraordinary career.

exhibition_title: Alfred Sisley
Jim Dine Prints: 1985-2000
exhibition_description: This retrospective of Jim Dine’s prints will span the last fifteen years of the artist’s graphic oeuvre. It will feature approximately 100 lithographs, intaglios, woodcuts and illustrated books published by Pace Editions, Graphicstudio and the Arion Press, among others. A fully illustrated raisonné will accompany the exhibition. This exhibition is the fourth in a series of print retrospectives and catalogue raisonnés, preceded by Galerie Mikro, Berlin, 1970; Williams College Museum of Art, Williamstown, MA, 1977; and the Davison Art Center and the Ezra and Cecile Zilkha Gallery, Wesleyan University, Middletown, CT, 1986.

exhibition_title: Governor's Residence: 2002-2008
Making Waves: The Vanguard Radio 1920-1950
Judaica 2002 - 2003
Ruth Bernhard: Photographs 1930s-1970s
exhibition_description: The exhibition will feature 60 of Ruth Bernhard’s most significant photographs made over a period of more than 40 years. Beginning as a young commercial photographer in New York in 1927, Bernhard relocated to San Francisco in 1953, which has since been her base of activity. Her peers and associates have included all the major West Coast photographers of the 20th century – Edward Weston, Imogene Cunningham, Dorothea Lange, Minor White.

exhibition_title: Marcel Breuer in Minnesota
exhibition_description: Hungarian-born Marcel Breuer (1902-1981) developed his tubular steel cantilevered chair, one of his many innovative furniture designs, while at the Bauhaus design school in Germany in the 1920s. After immigrating to the United States in 1937, he practiced architecture with Walter Gropius for a decade before opening his own successful office. His buildings, including the Whitney Museum in New York and Unesco Headquarters in Paris, are as visually arresting as his furniture, and he is regarded as one of the most important modern architect/designers of the twentieth century. “Marcel Breuer in Minnesota” is organized by the Minneapolis Institute of Arts to mark the centenary of Breuer’s birth. This exhibition will feature his Minnesota projects, including the Abbey Church and campus at St. John’s University in Collegeville, and two house projects, as well as his furniture designs from the Institute’s collection.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions
Amedeo Modigliani
Conversation Pieces: The Modern Telephone 1930-2000
Tzedakah
exhibition_description: The Jewish alms container known as the tzedekah box occupies a unique place among Jewish ritual objects.  Whereas other religious objects are bound by their ritual purpose, the tzedekah box is unaffiliated. The word tzedekah is derived from the root “tzadek”, meaning justice or righteousness. Tzedekah is the Jewish commandment to provide for those that are less fortunate as a means of bringing justice to the world. Tzedekah boxes come in all shapes in sizes thereby offering unlimited opportunities for artists to interpret them. The project will send an invitation to local Jewish and non-Jewish artists, inviting them to create a tzedekah box. Approximately 30 winning designs will be displayed at community sites and culminate with an exhibition at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts. The Tzedekah Box Project will challenge viewers/participants to question their own place in society; their responsibilities to their community; and their ability to be social change agents. It will ask us to reflect on ways in which we could have been changed by philanthropy and ways in which our community may have been transformed by another’s generosity.

exhibition_title: High Touch
exhibition_description: Artists Laura Stack and Anne Sugnet come to the abundance of the natural world - to its ever-shifting patterns of replication - with great reverence. Both artists have experienced profound events with the physical body and consider making art to be a transcendent action. Through their work they seek to create an antidote to a high speed, high-tech world that operates beyond human pace. Their exhibition "High Touch", which features Stack's luminous black and white drawings and Sugnet's intimate mixed-media installations, offers a poetic investigation into the very essence of things. Here we find slow amassed time, things becoming and unbecoming, traces of touch, and tender constellations of forms. In both bodies of work, primordial forms emerge - forms that suggest seeds, cones, spirals, cells dividing, or the cosmos. These shapes are familiar and there is comfort in that re-cognition. Yet they are located in mysterious spaces and for that they do not feel didactic but more like déjà vu - that fleeting sense of knowing, shrouded in mystery. It seems that you've been here before - perhaps in another life, perhaps as a cell or a star.

exhibition_title: Minton to Malibu: The Art of Glazed Tiles
exhibition_description: This exhibition traces the design history of ceramic tiles in America and Europe over the past three centuries, using examples from the Institute's own growing collection as well as those in private collections. The installation is organized in conjunction with the Tile Heritage Foundation’s annual meeting in the Twin Cities.

exhibition_title: Bridging America with Frank Lloyd Wright
exhibition_description: Bridging America with Frank Lloyd Wright celebrates the opening of the Marshall Field’s Bridge in Minneapolis, inspired by the work of Frank Lloyd Wright and designed by his successor firm, Taliesin Architects. The bridge, spanning Interstate 94 at Third Avenue South, forges a new connection between downtown Minneapolis, the Minneapolis Convention Center, and The Minneapolis Institute of Arts. To provide a context for the Marshall Field’s Bridge, the exhibition also examines over a dozen of Frank Lloyd Wright’s bridge projects through photo reproductions, models, and video. Produced over a sixty-year period, Wright’s designs range from simple footbridges in rural settings to multi-level, long-span urban bridges for both vehicles and pedestrians.

exhibition_title: Larry Rivers: Art and the Artist
Functionalism to Funk: California Ceramics
exhibition_description: This installation presents the work of ceramic artists in California from the 1940s, when renowned potters Beatrice Wood and Marguerite Wildenhain set up their wheels to make striking incised and glazed pots, through the present. “Functionalism to Funk” also tells the story of the irreverent “Funk” movement in ceramics that began in the 1960s with Robert Arneson’s comical portrait busts. The installation features several new ceramic sculptures in the Institute’s collection, including a monumental stack pot by Peter Voulkos and a bust by Arneson of Viola Frey (whose work is also represented in the exhibition).

exhibition_title: The Chair: Sculptural Form in Wood 1880-1960
Sacred Symbols: Four Thousand Years of Ancient American Art
exhibition_description:
The Sacred Symbols exhibition provided a unique opportunity to see the arts created by the people of the ancient Americas in all their beauty, variety and complexity. It featured works from a selection of the notable civilizations found throughout North, Central and South America, objects ranging in time of creation from 2500 BC to the initial period of contact with Europeans in the 16th century. These pieces represented a great variety of artistic styles powerfully expressing the fundamental religious, historical and political aspects of the lives of the people who created them.  
All of the approximately 180 objects in the exhibition were selected from the collections of American museums in the FRAME (French Regional American Museums Exchange) consortium and are masterpieces reflecting the strongest works available throughout the United States. Highlights of the show included elegant ceramics decorated with abstract and representational art designs from the Southwestern region of the present United States, as well as refined stone sculptures, ceramics and personal ornaments from the Southeast. Ancient Mexican cultures were represented by the superbly carved jade statues of figures and animals of the Olmec, the expertly painted ceramic vessels illustrating themes from mythology and history, and elaborately carved stone figures created by artists of the Maya civilization, and the inventive ceramic sculptures from the people of the Colima, Nayarit and Jalisco regions representing different aspects of everyday life.  From Central America there were magnificent golden ornaments fashioned in the form of human beings, mythological figures and animals, which were used by chiefs and other people of high status to adorn themselves and mark their status. There were also beautifully modeled and painted ceramics from Ancient Peru, representing individuals, animals and objects from the ceremonial and political culture of the Moche and Nazca people, plus some highly ornamented Incan vessels that showed the interaction of Nat
exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas

exhibition_title: Up the Nile: Egypt in 19th Century Photographs
exhibition_description: This exhibition features early photographic images made along the north-flowing Nile River, from Nubia to Lower Egypt. They meticulously depict the country’s renowned ancient monuments at such sites as Philae, Luxor, Karnak, and Giza. Dating from the late-nineteenth century, the photographs were made by professional photographers for tourists who flocked to Egypt on their “Grande Tour.” The exhibition consists of about fifty albumen prints by a half dozen photographers, including Felice Beato, Felix Bonfils, and Francis Frith. The work is drawn entirely from the Institute’s permanent collection and compliments the concurrent exhibition “Eternal Egypt.”

exhibition_title: R.P.M.
exhibition_description:
R.P.M. presents new work by Mollie Rabiner, J.J. Peet, and Don Myhre: interactive sculpture, fake (but possibly plausible) products and theatrical props  “scented” with humor. Yet all three broker serious ideas that, due to their cultural (or counter-cultural) underpinnings, can seem cautionary, subversive or even sinister. 
Mollie Rabiner invites the gallery visitor to try their luck with relationships and candy-coated desires by playing her stage-set, coin operated, carnival claw and digger machine. J.J. Peet presents a curious array of fake objects designed to carry extreme value or that allude to some secret information or event.  He questions the very nature of art through an assortment of found and handmade props -- bags of money; bricks of gold; a count-down-clock; and a mysterious brief case. Don Myhre presents a weird robotic amalgamation in his interactive sculpture, “Raft”. In it he combines a fiberglass jet ski, a downloaded landscape cast in foam, and a tattered taxidermied jackrabbit to create a whacked-out reference to the madness of American comodification.

exhibition_title: Three-Way Vision
exhibition_description: Three-Way Vision features new and recent bodies of work by artists Mary Carroll, Clea Felien, and Todd Severson who share notable technical mastery and who engage in what might be called a very obsessive aesthetic and process. The exhibition presents a wild assortment of work ranging from Carroll’s outrageously decorated ceramic vessels; to Felien’s familial portraits, drawn with her left hand and painted with her right; and Severson’s mammoth “collection” of chain saw portraits. “Three-Way Vision” reveals the complex assortment of issues that, for many artists living today, surround ideas about craft, facility, or documentation of culture.

exhibition_title: Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum
exhibition_description: Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum is the first major Egyptian exhibition to be drawn solely from the British Museum’s outstanding collection of Egyptian antiquities. Both renowned masterpieces and little-known treasures provide an overview of the richness and scope of this premiere collection of Egyptian art. The exhibition consists of 144 objects and spans the full range of pharaonic history, from shortly before the First Dynasty, about 3100 BC, to the Roman occupation of the fourth century AD. The four periods into which ancient Egyptian history is divided – the Old Kingdom, the Middle Kingdom, the New Kingdom, and the Late Period –form the underlying structure of the exhibition. A fully illustrated catalogue accompanies the exhibition. The catalogue is supported in part by Helen H. Scheidt.
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

exhibition_title: Portrait: 3 Meters per Second
Three Stories from Little America
exhibition_description: In this exhibition, Vince Leo presents nearly one hundred photographs of family and friends shot in Ohio between 1974 and 2000. Many of Leo’s subjects are depicted repeatedly through time and make up what one might consider and extraordinary, extended documentary that for Leo, exists as a particularly American Fairy Tale.

exhibition_title: Times Squared: Photographs by Toby Old
exhibition_description: Old’s work has always been characterized by a solid technical mastery of the medium format camera as the tool for his wonderfully zany, insightful and intelligent observation of the American scene. His subjects range from public events and situations such as Coney Island and Times Square, to county fairs, street theater, and professional boxing. Also included are images of the New York nightclub scene of the 1970s, fashion shows, and other displays of vanity and public preening. The photographs evoke an amusing though gently caustic, tongue-in-cheek satire on how we present ourselves to the world.

exhibition_title: Times Squared: Photographs by Toby Old
exhibition_description: Old’s work has always been characterized by a solid technical mastery of the medium format camera as the tool for his wonderfully zany, insightful and intelligent observation of the American scene. His subjects range from public events and situations such as Coney Island and Times Square, to county fairs, street theater, and professional boxing. Also included are images of the New York nightclub scene of the 1970s, fashion shows, and other displays of vanity and public preening. The photographs evoke an amusing though gently caustic, tongue-in-cheek satire on how we present ourselves to the world.

exhibition_title: Recent Acquisitions
exhibition_description: This exhibition will feature a selection of some of the MIA’s most notable recent acquisitions.

exhibition_title: Turner Drawings from the Taft Museum
Appreciating China: Gifts from Ruth and Bruce Dayton
exhibition_description:
The show will be comprised of approximately 300 Chinese and Tibetan works of art, purchased for the museum by Ruth and Bruce Dayton during the last 10 years. The exhibition is being formed to celebrate Bruce Dayton’s 60th year as a trustee of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts. Beginning about six years ago, the Daytons began to focus their donations in the area of Chinese art. Since that time, over 600 objects have been acquired in the categories of Chinese painting, Sung dynasty ceramics, Chinese lacquer, Chinese scholar items, classical Chinese furniture, Chinese woodblock printed hooks, Buddhist sculpture, Chinese archaeological objects, and Tibetan art. The unparalleled generosity of the Dayton’s has allowed the museum to build one of the finest overall collections of Chinese art in the west, and much of it will be shown for the first time during this exhibition.
A brochure of the exhibit is planned and a handbook of Chinese art featuring around 200 of these new works will be available during the final month of the exhibit in time for a symposium planned on the arts of China.

exhibition_title: Sesson Exhibition: A Super-Eccentric of Japan's Warring States Period
Sesson Exhibition: A Super-Eccentric of Japan's Warring States Period
Sesson Exhibition: A Super-Eccentric of Japan's Warring States Period
Sesson Exhibition: A Super-Eccentric of Japan's Warring States Period
Early Renaissance Engravings: North and South
exhibition_description: During the 15th century, printmaking emerged as a major artistic medium in Germany and Italy. A comparison of engravings produced in these two cultures will illustrate the different ways European engravers understood and expressed the new Renaissance ideals of humanism and naturalism.

exhibition_title: People in Porcelain
Contemporary Book Arts
Recent Acquisitions - January - April 2002
exhibition_description: This exhibition will feature a selection of some of the MIA’s most notable recent acquisitions.

exhibition_title: R.P.M. - August - Sept 2002
exhibition_description: Sculptor and installation artist, Welles Emerson is intrigued with visceral structures and environments that carry symbolic meaning -- structures such as bridges, fences, or places like ocean or an open field of grass. Emerson makes use of delicate tensions, connections and contradictions in her installations to maintain a similar emotional resonance. For her MAEP exhibition, Emerson presents a series of work related to fixed, mutable or transitory elements such as glass, waves of water or sound.

exhibition_title: Beyond Egypt: Exotic Art in the West
exhibition_description: Concurrent with Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum, this exhibition will explore American and European interest in the exotic cultures of northern Africa, India, and the Near East during the nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries. Stories will be revealed through an array of decorative and fine arts, primarily from the Institute's permanent collection.

exhibition_title: Falling Leaves: International Impressions
exhibition_description: Nature has always proved an inspiration for artists of all media. In this exhibition Scandinavian and American textile designers have drawn on the aesthetic sensibilities inherent in a range of artistic styles from the modernist movement to the emotional power of ethnographic art forms. Focusing on the leaf form, from bamboo to coffee plants, these 20th century designers have worked with a variety of textile producers from high tech Swiss mills to hand weavers in Thailand to express the power and diversity inherent in nature.

exhibition_title: Watercolors by J.M.W. Turner from the Taft Museum of Art
exhibition_description: The exhibition features ten watercolors by the renowned 19th-century British landscapist J.M.W. Turner on loan to the Institute of Arts from the Taft Museum of Art in Cincinnati, Ohio during renovation of the Taft's facilities. Spanning much of his career, the Taft watercolors are superb examples of Turner's pioneering work in this medium and demonstrate his genius both as a landscape artist and illustrator. Because of the fragility of the works to be displayed, the exhibition will be limited to a 9-week run.

exhibition_title: Echoes of the Heart: An Exhibition of Japanese Literati Paintings and Poetry
Echoes of the Heart: An Exhibition of Japanese Literati Paintings and Poetry
The Eye of the Traveler: David  Roberts' Egypt and the Holy Land
exhibition_description: The Scottish landscape painter David Roberts, R.A. (1796-1864) was among the first of a succession of European artists who ventured to the Middle East during the early decades of the nineteenth century to record the ancient monuments, religious sites, and cities of Egypt and the Holy Land. During an 11-month expedition that began in Alexandria, Egypt in 1838, Roberts produced hundreds of detailed sketches, drawings and watercolors of the region’s rich historical bounty, perceptively capturing its natural beauty and picturesque grandeur. This installation of David Roberts’ magnificent views of the Middle East was organized to complement the forthcoming exhibition “Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum.” The 20 prints on view are selected from the museum’s permanent collection as well as several private collections, including the Hennepin Avenue United Methodist Church in Minneapolis.

exhibition_title: Russian Avant-Garde
Delightful Pursuits: Highlights from the Lee Institute for Japanese Art at the Clark Center
Delightful Pursuits: Highlights from the Lee Institute for Japanese Art at the Clark Center
Delightful Pursuits: Highlights from the Lee Institute for Japanese Art at the Clark Center
Delightful Pursuits: Highlights from the Lee Institute for Japanese Art at the Clark Center
Delightful Pursuits: Highlights from the Lee Institute for Japanese Art at the Clark Center
Stefano Della Bella (1610-64) and Giovanni Benedetto Castiglione (1616-70): Master Etchers of the Italian Baroque
exhibition_description:
Stefano Della Bella was a highly prolific printmaker whose oeuvre numbers over a thousand etchings. He was employed extensively by the Medici Family both at Florence and Rome. He is best known for his depictions of court festivals, funeral ceremonies, theatrical productions, hunting scenes and military themes. The present installation included 50 etchings by Della Bella. 
Giovanni Benedetto Castiglione, a native of Genoa, was primarily a painter of religious, historical and mythological themes. During the late 1640s, Castiglione executed about 114 etchings; he also experimented with the medium of monotype. Ten etchings are on display in this exhibition.

exhibition_title: Kamisaka Sekka: Rimpa Master-- Pioneer of Modern Design
Kamisaka Sekka: Rimpa Master-- Pioneer of Modern Design
Kamisaka Sekka: Rimpa Master-- Pioneer of Modern Design
Kamisaka Sekka: Rimpa Master-- Pioneer of Modern Design
Paul Granlund: A Retrospective
A Man and His Garden: Textiles from the Jack Lenor Larsen Archive
Jan Van Der Streadanus: 16th Century Flemish Engravings and Woodcuts
Judaica 2003 - 2004
Bruce Rogers
Illustrating Influence: The Origins of Baroque Cities in Central Europe
From Hawthorne to Hofmann: Provincetown Vignettes, 1899-1945
Girodet Examination
A Woman's Way: Feminine Attire in 20th Century Morocco
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured objects drawn from the Textiles and Africa, Oceania, and the Americas collections as well as selected pieces from a private collection. The focus of the installation is on Berber, Jewish, and Arab influences on female clothing styles of rural and urban Moroccan women during the 20th century. Changing styles and cultural adaptations were shown featuring festive and holiday clothing.

exhibition_title: Symphony in Black and White: 100 Etchings and Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler
exhibition_description: James Abbott McNeill Whistler died on July 17, 1903, making this year the centenary of his death. This exhibition celebrated the career and life of this extraordinary artist. The Minneapolis Institute of Arts has over 100 etchings and lithographs by Whistler that formed the core of the exhibition. As an etcher, Whistler took inspiration from Rembrandt and the Dutch masters that he discovered in the print collection of his brother in law, Francis Seymour Haden. Works by these artists were on view, allowing the visitor to see the path of Whistler's development as a printmaker. Whistler was a charismatic and challenging personality whose art and ideas influenced numerous other artists. This exhibition also included works by those who were members of Whistler's circle of admirers and followers, allowing the visitor to see the wide path Whistler cut across the art world. His influence was not only seen in the prints and paintings of the day, but also in the interiors and decorative arts his gathered around him. The exhibition was augmented by a selection of decorative arts, Japanese prints, and other objects that would have graced a Whisterian interior. The exhibition cut across numerous curatorial departments to create a stunning picture of the world of James Abbott McNeill Whistler.

exhibition_title: The Twin Cities Collects: The Ceramics of Edwin and Mary Scheier
exhibition_description: Americans Edwin and Mary Scheier (b. 1910 and b. 1908) took a circuitous route to the world of pottery, by way of art school, odd jobs, puppeteering, and positions with the Works Progress Administration during the 1930s. By 1940 their lively pots of Virginia clay won awards at the prestigious Ceramic National at Syracuse, New York. As a result, Ed was offered a teaching position at the University of New Hampshire, where he and Mary produced hundreds of beautifully potted wares often decorated with Ed’s expressive human figures or abstract sgraffito decoration. In the late 1960s, the Scheiers’ move to Mexico resulted in exciting work in new media including weaving design and wooden sculpture. After the Scheiers settled in Arizona in 1978, Ed returned with renewed vigor to clay and has over the past several years created original computer art. This exhibition, celebrated the wealth of work by the Scheiers in local public and private collections, included approximately forty-five ceramic pieces, as well as other objects in a variety of media from their 60-plus years as a creative team.

exhibition_title: Art Deco: The French Aesthetic
exhibition_description:
In the summer of 1971, The Minneapolis Institute of Arts organized and presented an encyclopedic exhibition devoted to Art Deco.  Nearly 1,500 works culled from private and public collections in Europe and America represented the most ambitious effort ever to assess this diverse, international, "un-style" which stubbornly defies ready definition.
Thirty-two years later, in this encore reprise, the focus wais purposely narrowed to luxurious French designs drawn solely from the Institute's holdings, all acquired since the 1971 exhibition. The work of Sèvres, Jean Puiforcat, René Lalique, Boch Fréres, Robert Mallet-Stevens, La Maison Desny and Edgar Brandt were among twenty-five select pieces — haute and nouvelle — documenting Art Deco's diverse phases, from the classical-elegant, to the exotic-expressive, and ultimately, to the austere-moderne.

exhibition_title: Unprepared
exhibition_description: This was an exhibition of neo-feminist narratives by printmakers Faye Passow and Jenny Schmid. Faye Passow that dealt with feminine identity and family dysfunction in a series of humorous lithographs depicting multiple calamities converging on small family groups. Jenny Schmid’s double-edged work deals with the drug use of women and girls through history. Inspired by historical documents, especially the 19th century use of morphine to “calm the nerves” of depressed young women, Schmid’s lithographs presented allegorical images of “things that cause teen-aged girls to be bad”.

exhibition_title: The Russian Avant-Garde:  Artist's Books, Prints, and Posters 1912-1925
exhibition_description: First comprehensive display of our Russian modernist graphic collection that we first began to acquire in 1989—about 30 pieces. The artists included Kandinsky, Goncharova, El Lissitzky, Malevich, Rodchenko, Larionov, and David and Vladimir Burliuk.

exhibition_title: Della Bella & Castiglione: Master Etchers of the Italian Baroque
The World Through His Eyes: Works on Paper by Joseph Pennell
exhibition_description:
Drawn entirely from the permanent collection of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts, this selection of 24 etchings, lithographs, and drawings by the American artist Joseph Pennell (1857-1926) highlighted his ability to create a highly personal communication with his subject. Whether a view of skyscrapers in New York, London’s famous sites, the construction of the Panama Canal, or a far off view of a cathedral in the French countryside, you know that “Pennell was there”—and perhaps recall when you were.
A complex, opinionated intellectual and a leader in the Golden Age of American illustration, Pennell wrote many books on art, artists and his travels. His work was his supreme interest and amusement in life, and these examples of his graphic art showed us the legacy of an important artist.

exhibition_title: The Art of Herbs
Everyday Beauty: Guatemalan Huipils
exhibition_description: Traditionally people throughout the world mark special occasions such as festivals, weddings and religious holidays by wearing elaborate clothing, often made of costly materials. Guatemalan women are particularly noted for their elaborate, handwoven brocade fabrics. In addition to their traditional ceremonial clothing, however, native women frequently celebrate the beauty of cloth every day by wearing brightly patterned woven or embroidered blouses called huipils. Drawing on recent acquisitions to the museum's extensive holding of Guatemalan textiles, this small exhibition celebrated the creative diversity of eight different villages and their distinctive response to the inherent potential of beauty in everyday life.

exhibition_title: Buildings to Bank On: Selections from the Katherine Kierland Herberger Collection of Banks
exhibition_description: Katherine Herberger did not set out to have one of the most significant collections of antique still and mechanical banks in the country, but at the time of her death in 2003, her collection included more than 1,300 examples. The Katherine Kierland Herberger Collection of Banks found a permanent home at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts, where a newly dedicated gallery on the ground floor between the Family Center and classrooms showcases rotating exhibitions of the collection. The first exhibition, titled “Buildings to Bank On: Selections from the Katherine Kierland Herberger Collection of Banks,” featured more than one hundred examples of architectural banks that are sure to delight visitors of all ages.

exhibition_title: Northern Visions: Art and Life of the Inuit
exhibition_description: This exhibition presented Inuit sculpture and prints lent by the Winnipeg Art Gallery, which has one of the world's largest and well-known collections of Inuit art, and featured objects from private collectors as well as the Institute's collection. Displaying mostly contemporary artwork from several Inuit communities located in northern Canada, "Northern Visions" explored significant themes in Inuit art such as animals, hunting, and origins and myths.
exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas

exhibition_title: Legacy of the Lathe: Gifts of Turned Wood from Robyn and John Hern and their Circle of Friends
Drawn to Perfection: American Photorealist Graphics

Recent Acquisitions - February 2003 to April 2003
exhibition_description: This exhibition will feature a selection of some of the MIA’s most notable recent acquisitions.

exhibition_title: Seven Centuries of Chinese Painting: Recent Gifts from Joan Wurtele
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured more than thirty of the Chinese paintings acquired in recent years through the generosity of Joan Wurtele. The exhibit included small, lyrical landscapes and bird and flower paintings of the Southern Sung dynasty (1127–1279); delicate ink landscapes of the important early Ming (1368–1644); as well as work by Wu school artists, and some fine Buddhist paintings. Also included were representative professional and literati landscape paintings of the late Ming and Ch’ing dynasties (1644–1911), including works by Ku I-te (active 1608–33), Cha Shih-piao (1615–98), Kung Hsien (1619–89), and Lan Ying (1585-1664). Each of these paintings was selected with the museum’s collecting needs in mind. Care was taken to add significant scrolls that helped achieve our goal of building as representative and high quality a collection of Chinese paintings as possible.
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

exhibition_title: Grotto: an alternative reality by bill klaila
exhibition_description:
The magical mind and art of Bill Klaila is fueled by a passion for the landscape and an uncommon appreciation for alternative reality.  His latest virtual installation was entitled "Grotto", an interactive environment that immersed the viewer and responded to his or her passage through it. The interactivity of Klaila's 21st century landscape paid homage to the intelligence of the living landscape and reflected Klaila's dynamic experience with the world. 
To create the environment, Klaila employed three different computers, a pressure sensitive floor (grid) and modified video game software that synchronizes layered scenes and projected graphic displays. As the viewer stepped into Klaila's Grotto the floor grid sent a signal to the computers telling them where the viewer was and how much pressure was present. The floor graphic read like water on the floor of a cave. Each step sent the water splashing and rippling to reflect off of the walls of the cave.

exhibition_title: Modernist Kitchenware: The Counter Revolution, 1930-1960
exhibition_description:
Kitchenware?!!  What comes to mind for many are pots and pans and potato peelers, perhaps. But, have you ever seen a Hollywood Liquefier, a toaster with a built-in conveyer belt, a “Coffee X” cold water extractor, a rotating “Twin-O-Matic” waffle iron, a “Top-O-Stove” potato baker, or our newest acquisition, a muscle-bound meat slicer, the pride of the pantry?
 
The third exhibition in the Institute’s “Case Studies in Design” series is devoted to modernist kitchenware.  Ingenuity is often synonymous with modernity and such is the case with nearly forty works selected for this exhibition. Are you aware that one of the foremost designers represented in the exhibition, Harold Van Doren, served as Assistant Director of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts?
 
Comprised of kitchenware drawn from the Institute’s collection, complemented with additional loans, the works are inventive collaborations between designers, engineers, manufacturers and advertising agents resulting in some of the most remarkable utensils and appliances of the era.  The one element missing is the aroma of freshly-brewed coffee, pancakes, maple syrup and crisp bacon.  Nevertheless, it is an exhibition for all ages, homemakers or not.

exhibition_title: Declaration of Independence Road Trip
exhibition_description: This traveling multi media exhibition presented one of the 25 remaining original copies (the Dunlap broadsides) of the Declaration of Independence, printed on July 4, 1776. Using historical and contemporary photographs, video and music, the exhibition illustrated the values and ideals embodied in the Declaration of Independence. The installation also highlighted the social and political movements that helped shape the United States. In addition to the document itself, the installation featured a 14 minute film of a reading of the Declaration of Independence at Independence Hall in Philadelphia.

exhibition_title: Apocalypse
exhibition_description: Albrecht Durer's Apocalypse stands as one the major achievements of pictorial art. His series of dramatic woodcuts are the production of his imaginative power and splendid draftsmanship, and introduces his new conception of the black and white print as an independent work of art. This exhibition presented the Institute's complete series of the 1511 edition.

exhibition_title: Governor's Residence: 2003-2012
Printmaking in the Age of Romanticism
exhibition_description: This exhibition highlighted a selection of lithographs, etchings, and mezzotints from the Institute ’s permanent collection that exemplify the tenets of Romanticism. The artists Eugène Delacroix, Théodore Géricault, Richard Parkes Bonnington, and J.M.W. Turner were active participants in this movement that valued imagination, emotion, exotic cultures, nature, and the literature of Byron, Scott, and Shakespeare. These and other related themes were explored in the works on display. The Romantic era stretched from the French Revolution in 1789 until the middle of the 19th  century, with the most intense period of production beginning with the demise of Napoleon in 1815 and progressing until the early 1840s. While many of the artists represented in the exhibition are better known as painters, this exhibition revealed that they were also talented practitioners of lithography and etching.  Featured prints included selections from Gericault’s English Set, J.M.W. Turner’s Liber Studiorum, and Bonnington’s views of Paris and Rouen, as well as Delacroix’s Royal Tiger.

exhibition_title: Shaped with a Passion: The Carl A. Weyerhaeuser Collection of Japanese Ceramics from the 1970s
exhibition_description: The exhibition featured 120 pieces of contemporary Japanese ceramics collected by Carl A. Weyerhauser in 1972 – 1973 and now housed in the Art Complex Museum, Duxbury, Massachusetts. In amassing the collection, every attempt was made to gather from different geographical areas in Japan, each representing a historic legacy of ceramic production. In addition to already recognized master potters — some designated Living National Treasures— remarkable works by emerging artists were also collected. The exhibition reflects the monolithic influence of the tea ceremony on Japanese ceramic production with the majority of the selected works, in form and technique, related to traditional tea wares.
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

exhibition_title: Jasper Johns: Numbers
Crossing the Channel: British and French Painting in the Age of Romanticism
exhibition_description: This exhibition explored the relationship between French and British painting during the 1820s and 1830s when fascination with every level of Anglo-Scottish culture played a formative role in the development of modern French art. Approximately 120 paintings by 60 artists, including Turner, Bonington, Constable, Delacroix, Géricault, and Corot were on view. An exhibition catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Crossing the Channel: British and French Painting in the Age of Romanticism
exhibition_description: This exhibition explored the relationship between French and British painting during the 1820s and 1830s when fascination with every level of Anglo-Scottish culture played a formative role in the development of modern French art. exhibition_title: Crossing the Channel: British and French Painting in the Age of Romanticism

exhibition_title: Household Names: The Designer in American Life
exhibition_description: How have Americans become aware of who designs their everyday objects? With the advent of industrial production in the mid-19th century, household goods flooded European and American homes, but they were for the most part unattractive, owing to the little regard manufacturers gave toward their appearance. The 1930s introduced Americans to industrial designers such as Raymond Loewy, Henry Dreyfuss, and Walter Dorwin Teague, who became well known through their streamlined approach to everything from automobiles to thermostats, and through their books on the subject of design. By the 1940s, as consumers began to embrace modern design, manufacturers made a point of marketing goods under the “brand names”of their designers. Russel and Mary Wright and Charles and Ray Eames positioned themselves as practitioners of a new, casual lifestyle for which their modern products were perfectly suited. Today, with the faces and signatures of Philippe Starck and Michael Graves prominently featured on packaging, designers are often better known than their merchandise. Through objects from the Institute’s collection and from private collections, “Household Names”examines the designer’s rise to recognition in modern Ameerica.

exhibition_title: Courts of the Baroque Age: From Bernini and Velázquez to Luca Giordano
An Artist's Paradise: Minnesota Landscapes 1840-1940
Francis Bacon and the Tradition of Art
Francis Bacon and the Tradition of Art
Eugène Delacroix, 1798-1863
Walker Evans
exhibition_description: Walker Evans’s crisp, authoritative images helped define the documentary style of photography that flourished between the World Wars. Working for the U.S. government in the 1930s, Evans created his most significant body of work, essaying the vernacular architecture and rural poor of the Deep South. This exhibition consisted of about fifty of these stunning, vintage photographs. They were drawn entirely from the Institute’s permanent collection, which has one of the country’s most significant holdings of Evans’s work. A catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Long Afternoon: Celeste Nelms and Carolyn Swiszcz
exhibition_description: “Long Afternoon” featured new work by Celeste Nelms and Carolyn Swiszcz, two artists who share an uncommon affection for things well past their prime. In their exhibition of photographs and mixed media paintings, they both paid homage to things created and treasured, later caste off or forgotten.

exhibition_title: "Art That's Really Moving" and "Can't Leave it Alone"
exhibition_description:
Timothy Fort’s “Art That’s Really Moving” featured ongoing footage of Fort’s kinetic arrangements. Tim Fort is obsessed with the magic of static objects coming to life and has designed hundreds of domino tumbles and exploding Popsicle sticks and playing card sculpture. 

Gerald Smith’s “Can’t Leave it Alone” presented a working studio, including evidence of past work, a host of artificial satellites and silent documentary films. Smith’s studio centered on a work-in-progress about the science of human cloning, that premiered during the run of the show.

exhibition_title: George Washington: A National Treasure
exhibition_description: The 205-year-old portrait of George Washington is considered an American treasure compared to that of the Liberty Bell and the Declaration of Independence. It is commonly called the “Lansdowne” portrait, the title derived from the name of the person for whom it was painted, the Marquis of Lansdowne. Senator William Bingham commissioned it in 1796 for the marquis, a British support of the American cause during the American Revolution. The artist is Gilbert Stuart, the preeminent portraitist in the United States in the early 19th century. Stuart painted nearly 1,000 portraits in his lifetime including Paul Revere, Abigail Adams, Mohawk Chief Joseph Brandt as well as George Washington and numerous other U.S. presidents. In spring of 2001 the National Portrait Gallery acquired the “Lansdowne” portrait through a generous gift from the Donald W. Reynolds Foundation.

exhibition_title: Werner Bischof: Life and Work of a Photographer 1916 - 1954
exhibition_description: Born in Zürich, Switzerland 26 April 1916, Werner Bischof began his career in studio photography. Following service in the Swiss army, he documented Europe in the aftermath of World War II. The devastation he recorded there was to influence his work for the rest of his life. He joined the Magnum Photographic agency in 1949 and continued to focus on the ‘face of human suffering’. One of his most well known photo-essays on ‘Famine in India’ was published in Life magazine the same year. He also completed assignments in Korea, Okinawa and Japan. He covered the stories of refugees from Mao’s China and the war in Indochina. Werner Bischof died in May 1954 at the age of 38 while on assignment for Magnum and Life in Peru. This exhibition included more than 65 prints covering the Studio Period, Europe After the War and Traveling the World.

exhibition_title: P.R.S.S.
exhibition_description:
Artists Richard Shelton and Piotr Szyhalski collaborated for the first time to create an interactive installation called P.R.S.S. for the Minnesota Artists Exhibition Program. P.R.S.S. was inspired by the artists' fascination with the radical investigations of John C. Lilly, Stanley Milgram, Kasimir Malevich, and Ivan P. Pavlov. The exhibition dealt with essential aspects of contemporary human behavior by reflecting on particular dynamics of learning, perception, moral position, resistance, and the disconnections among us all. The P.R.S.S. installation was composed of four chambers in which the viewer experienced a series of virtual images and sounds and participated in their alteration. It was the artists' intention that a range of visceral, emotional, and spiritual responses be experienced through a non-linear installation.

P.R.S.S. was inspired by the artists' independent studies: Shelton was fascinated with the neural research of Lilly, a scientist obsessed with dolphins, LSD, and with his own self-inflicted isolation experiments; and with Milgram, who is known for his obedience (shock) experiments, performed after the Nuremberg trials, and for the famous theory that no one is more that six degrees removed from anyone else. Szyhalski focused on the Suprematist painting of Malevich, who stripped his art down to its very essence (a black square), and Pavlov, a scientist famous for his research with the conditioned reflex of dogs. P.R.S.S. is not intended to pay homage to these four historical figures, but rather to reflect some of the principles of their work.

Each artist created two of the four chambers. Piotr Szyhalski's first chamber set up a situation in which things happen while the viewer holds still. In Szyhalski's second chamber he set out to create a pure state of emotion, looking directly at the violence that humans inflict on each other. exhibition_title: Recent Acquisitions - November 2003 - April 2004
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured a selection of some of the MIA’s most notable recent acquisitions.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions: A White House Christmas
exhibition_description:
Since Calvin Coolidge lit the first official White House Christmas tree in 1923, American presidents have communicated holiday greetings through public addresses, cards, prints, and other gifts. This year's "Holiday Traditions" offered insight into Christmas at the White House. The Bell Family Decorative Arts Court featured mementos from the 1930s to the present, including the card for which this Wyeth painting was commissioned, and a rare example of the card signed by President Kennedy just days before his assassination.

Costumed guides offer tours of the Bell Court and the Period Rooms several times each day.

Three Centuries of Tradition: The Renaissance of Custom Sporting Arms in America
exhibition_description: Three Centuries of Tradition featured examples of work by living American gunmakers known for their translations of traditional European, British, and American sporting arms of various styles made between 1640 and 1940. An introductory section featured sporting arms made during that timeframe which served as stylistic and technological guides for contemporary work. Three Centuries of Tradition presented custom-made sporting arms as consummate examples of the decorative arts, demonstrating the highest artistic achievements in carving, inlay, and engraving of metal and wood. Guest curators for the exhibition include gunsmith Mark Silver, and Wallace Gusler, Master Gunsmith at Colonial Williamsburg. A catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Our Noble Steeds
The Miller Collection of Roman Sculpture: Mythological Figures and Protraits
exhibition_description: This refined exhibition of Roman sculpture features over thirty stone portraits dating from the first through third centuries. Selected from the private holdings of New York collector Dr. Michael Miller, the show is comprised of three-dimensional heads, relief fragments, and full figures. Features in the display are royal portraits including those of emperors Diocletian and Caesar Augustus; several private portraits of the aristocracy as well as a group of mythological portraits including Hercules, Cupid, and Zeus. The exhibit provides the viewer a fascinating look at some of the personalities, intriguing iconography, and refined sculpting techniques of classical antiquity that are not available in the museum’s permanent collection of Roman sculpture. This thematic exhibit appeals tremendously to scholars and students of Roman art and anyone interested in classical history and art. A fully illustrated catalogue by Dr. Richard Brilliant accompanies the exhibition.
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

exhibition_title: Currents of Change: Art and Life Along the Mississippi River, 1850-1861
exhibition_description:
America’s development was at one of its most dramatic moments in the 1850s, a decade celebrated along the Mississippi River as the 50th anniversary of the Louisiana Purchase and the westward expedition of Lewis and Clark. Currents of Change will explore the fine and decorative arts along the river during that period. America was undergoing extraordinary changes: from the steamboat era to the advent of the railroad, from a mostly agrarian economy to the beginnings of the industrial revolution, from a nation of youthful optimism to one which would soon erupt into civil war. Fortunes made from lumber and lead processing in the North and cotton and sugar production in the South gave birth to the great cities along the river that we know today, and financed the demand for sophisticated furnishings and a “refined” life. The Mississippi, which had long been a channel for trade, was becoming an important conduit for ideas about art, culture, and design.
Currents of Change brings together approximately 175 objects in all media: paintings, prints, and drawings, furniture, silver, ceramics, textiles, and sculpture. The exhibition includes a 16-foot segment from the only extant panorama of the Mississippi River (a 340-foot-long moving landscape), to be shown in a theatrical setting that recalls how viewers of the 1850s would have seen it.
An illustrated catalogue accompanies the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Beauford Delaney: From New York to Paris
exhibition_description: Beauford Delaney, an African-American, was an artist who produced works of great diversity and technical complexity who has, unfortunately, remained relatively unknown to the general public. While his pursuit of art began in his native Knoxville, Tennessee, and continued over a five-year period in Boston, the years that followed (1929-1979) were the most innovative and productive of the artist’s life. His career is generally broken into two parts: the New York Years (1929-1953), during which time Delaney produced his colorful and highly-engaging compositions of the City’s urban landscape; and the Paris years (1953-1979) when the artist, known as “the dean of American Negro painters” in Paris, embraced abstract expressionism in a study of color and light. The Institute’s presentation, for the first time, provides a survey of the progression of his work. The exhibition brings forth transitional works that have not previously been considered and illuminate his place within American art history. The exhibition consists of approximately forty paintings and ten works on paper borrowed from institutional and private collections in America and Europe.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions
exhibition_description:
Packages of all sorts have come a long way since the plain brown bundles depicted in Victorian Christmas scenes. Advances in construction, printing, and mechanization throughout the 20th century have resulted in “graphic” developments for the simple shopping bag and hatbox.  They serves as portable billboards for the store, and once home, can live on as containers for keepsakes—often becoming keepsakes themselves. As department stores and boutiques increasingly consider packaging as an extension of their service and identity, they look to designers for more attractive wrappings. Artists such as Erté, Roy Lichtenstein, Salvador Dali, Andy Warhol, and Frank Stella have accepted commissions to design shopping bags, many of them considered portable art by museums and collectors.  
In the Twin Cities, such fashion-forward retailers as Young-Quinlan, Field-Schlick, and Dayton’s invested considerable effort and imagination into their packaging. The Institute will feature these and other designs from local shops in the Bell Decorative Arts Court during this year’s Holiday Traditions exhibition, on view in the Period Rooms and at the Purcell-Cutts house November 26, 2004 through January 2, 2005. Costumed docents will offer tours from Thanksgiving through New Year’s Eve.

exhibition_title: Seurat and the Making of "La Grande Jatte"
Grant Wood: Main Street
Light Bound: Photographers Regard the Book
exhibition_description: This exhibition includes the work of seven contemporary artists who have extensively photographed books.  Working over the last ten years, as electronic publishing emerged, these photographers celebrated the traditional book, made of ink, paper, and glue. Their works show books as purveyors of popular culture, objects of physical beauty, vessels of information, and symbols of human knowledge. The exhibition consists of about 60 photographs and one installation by: Sally Alatalo, Peter Beard, James Henkel, Doug Keyes, Abelaredo Morell, Alison Rossiter, and JoAnn Verburg.

The Hmong Migration
exhibition_description: This exhibition features fifty paintings by Cy Thao that documents the history of the Hmong people. Thao’s series begins with Hmong creation myths and chronologically depicts the migration of the Hmong community from Southern China, to the mountains of Laos, to the refugee camps of Thailand and finally to life in Minnesota. Now a community activist and Representative in the Minnesota State Legislature, Cy Thao was born in Laos in 1972. His family spent the first two years of his life trying to escape the war and the next five starving in a refugee camp. Thao’s family came to Minnesota in 1980.

exhibition_description: This exhibition of fifteen works on paper pays tribute to the relationship between Minneapolis resident Robert O. Fisch, M.D., a Holocaust survivor from Budapest, Hungary, and students from America and Eastern Europe who have heard him talk about his experiences.

exhibition_title: A Medieval Mystery: Who Was the Master of the Embroidered Foliage?
exhibition_description: This exhibition brings together for the first time four versions of the Master of the Embroidered Foliage’s hallmark image from public collections in the United States, Belgium, and France. The fifteenth-century Netherlandish painter—so named for the delicately patterned and crisply executed blades of grass and plants that resemble embroidery in his paintings—is best known for his panel paintings of the Virgin and Child with a book. Virtually identical in composition, these works feature Mary in voluminous robes sitting on a throne while the Christ child in her arms leafs precociously through the pages of an illuminated manuscript. The Master’s panels differ in their settings and other decorative details, however. Some feature landscape backgrounds while others show city streets. Angels, peacocks, or contemporary burghers embellish the pictures alternatively. Rich in palette and pattern, the panels are finely painted with an eye for detail characteristic of Northern Renaissance painters of this era, which include Rogier van der Weyden (c. 1399-1464), upon whose works the Master’s are based. An illustrated catalogue will be published on the occasion of the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Just One Word: PLASTICS
exhibition_description:
"I just want to say one word to you.  Just one word....Plastics....  There's a great future in plastics." This brief pronouncement appearing in the 1968 film, "The Graduate," convulsed audiences then, but since has taken on an entirely new meaning. In the span of some 35 years, the entire spectrum of plastics — that "miracle material" — has risen from ridicule to respect (occasionally reverence) and, yet again, a scourge-like contempt when it comes to matters of biodegradable disposal.
In a two-part examination and celebration of innovative plastic design, a first installment will appear in Wells Fargo Gallery of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts followed by a second, overlapping presentation at Wells Fargo Center in downtown Minneapolis. It is the first such arrangement utilizing the city-center facility to expand on a given theme originating at the Institute.
Today, nothing underscores the technological revolution more than plastics. Not since the early 20-century popularity of Bakelite (which will be featured in a simultaneous Institute installation as part of the on-going "Case Studies" Series) has plastic been so admired. Tutti-frutti colors, sensuous, tactile surfaces, transparent forms, groovy fusions of art and chemistry, and phenomenal tensile strength are but a few of the qualities fulfilling design needs beyond mere function. In the 21st century, functionality has become multi-dimensional and plastics appear to promise ever-expanding purpose and pleasure.

Above Is Below: Sarah Chokyi Bauer and David Hamlow
exhibition_description: “Above is Below” features the spiritually based art of Sarah Chokyi Anne Bauer and David Hamlow. Whose distinct bodies of work have evolved out of long-term meticulously defined daily practice. The exhibition will present an installation of repetitive images by Bauer, who holds sacred Buddhist ritual at the core of her artistic inquiry; and a structure built by Hamlow, who records his daily life by saving, sorting and arranging the commercial packaging and detritus of his daily consumption.

exhibition_title: Lillian's Vision
exhibition_description: "Lillian's Vision" features a vast array of crop art portraits by the legendary Lillian Colton, a self-taught, 92 year-old artist who has used seeds as her primary medium for 39 years. Collectively, Colton's icons of historical or entertainment celebrity span many decades of pop culture, from American presidents, to the stars of the silent screen, of pop art, of country music, and rock and roll, to great leaders in religion and science. "Lillian's Vision" is presented by the Minnesota Artists Exhibition Program and is organized by guest curator, artist Jan D. Elftmann.

exhibition_title: Hot & Cool: The Jazz Posters of Niklaus Troxler
exhibition_description:
An extensive suite of dramatic jazz posters by the Swiss graphic designer, Niklaus Troxler, will be presented in the U.S. Bank Gallery. Drawn from a collection of post-war posters acquired by Norwest Corporation in 1991, they exemplify the celebrated Swiss International Style initiated decades earlier. Thelonious Monk, McCoy Tyner, Alvin Jones, Arthur Blythe, the Roscoe Mitchell Quartet and Sam Rivers Quartet are but a few of the influential jazz musicians represented. 
Niklaus Troxler (b. 1947) is best known for his striking posters for the Jazz festival at Willisau, Switzerland. He studied at the Kunstgewerbeschule, Lucerne (1968-71) and worked briefly as art director at Hollenstein Creation in Paris before founding his own studio in Willisau in 1973. Troxler has been the recipient of numerous design awards, but his work to date is little known in America.
In their small hometown of Willisau, Troxler and his brother founded a jazz festival in 1975 which soon became world famous. Ever since, Troxler has remained the most prolific and talented of jazz posters artists. While there have been many jazz festivals over the years, none have produced a series of graphics that compare with Troxler’s memorable design. He continues to work in a select field he’s made his own.
Pictorial simplicity, bold color fields, rational order, compressed spatial compositions and innovative letterforms are among the qualities that distinguish this group of jazz posters. Clarity and immediacy are the two key ingredients conveyed in multilingual formats meant to transcend language and cultural barriers.
The Swiss poster movement had a decisive impact on postwar American graphic design, spreading a new “internationalism” in the print world. This cohesive set of posters represents a convergence of two distinct sensibilities: American improvisational jazz and the cerebral order of Swiss graphic design.

Fabulous Photographic Ephemera
exhibition_description: Millions of ephemeral items related to find and applied photography are produced each year. The items are usually time sensitive, small in size, and rarely saved. They include posters, letters, labels, brochures, and other items primarily made of paper. They can provide valuable bits of historic information, such as prices or exhibition dates. In addition, they sometimes yield personal information about photographers, humanizing them or showcasing their opinions. This exhibition includes about 100 objects of photographic ephemera from the files and collection of the Department of Photographs at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts. The material includes objects relating to Ansel Adams, Diane Arbus, Richard Avedon, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Edward S. Curtis, and many other major photographers.

Bakelite: Art through Chemistry
exhibition_description:
While plastic is considered a "now" medium, the modern plastics industry stretches back to the 1920s and the mass production of Bakelite. Its potential was first developed in 1907 by Dr. Leo Hendrik Baekeland (1863-1944), now regarded as the "Father of Plastics." As a simultaneous complement to the Institute's "Just One Word: PLASTICS" exhibition, "Bakelite: Art Through Chemistry" will be on view concurrently, from March 6 to February 27, 2005. The latter is a continuation of the museum's "Case Studies in Design" series.  
Significantly, Bakelite has earned the distinction of being the world's very first totally synthetic, thermosetting plastic.  It quickly found its way into homes and offices in a wide assortment of objects, many represented in this exhibition, ranging from kitchenware, household and office wares, to electronics, cameras, tools and jewelry. "Its versatility extended from cradle to grave" boasted advertisements in 1939.
Molten Bakelite flowed evenly and gave rise to the smooth, "streamline" style so pervasive in the l930s.  At that time the ideological thrust of Modernism stressed the importance of new materials such as Bakelite and, in turn, plastics became firmly associated with the ideals and spread of modern design.

exhibition_title: Imperial Perfection: Chinese Palace Procelain of Three Great Emperors
exhibition_description:
One hundred porcelains, each made specifically for the Chinese court and bearing an imperial reign mark will be the focus of this extraordinarily beautiful exhibition. Drawn from one of the world’s finest private Chinese collections of Ch’ing dynasty imperial ware, the show focuses entirely on court porcelain of the Kang’his (1662 – 1722), Yung Cheng (1723 – 1735) and Ch’ien-lung (1736 – 1795) reigns. This style of the era is exemplified by the use of brilliant colors, innovative designs, and technical refinement that have never been surpassed. The exhibit features exceptional monochromatic porcelains of gem-like purity, stunning blue-and-white vessels full of imperial dragon imagery, and a dazzling overview of brightly decorated, polychrome wares. 
A fully illustrated catalogue by Julian Thompson accompanies the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Top Mix
exhibition_description: Minneapolis artist Alyn Silberstein presents Top Mix, an audacious and eye-popping installation of large-scale digital prints. Using sophisticated computer hardware, software, and printing technologies, Silberstein samples and manipulates digital photos to create lush abstract images that are rich in color, texture, and pattern. It is ultramodern image-making fused with ancient and traditional motifs. These stunning prints are installed on walls decorated with floor-to-ceiling murals to create a truly mind-bending visual experience.

Flemish Fantasia: Invention and Imagination in Sixteenth Century Flemish Engravings
exhibition_description: Mannerism, a refined artistic style originating in Italy, took hold in Flanders in the 16th century, bringing with it a new repertoire of subjects, techniques, and sensibilities. It coincided with the rapid development of printmaking, especially engraving, by Flemish artists. Master engravers such as Pieter Breugel the Elder and Hendrick Goltzius transformed the role of prints from being mere book illustrations to works of art in their own right, avidly collected by the newly prosperous merchant class.

Papermade Modernism
exhibition_description: Today, the episode of Modernism has been examined in considerable detail.  But papermade objects seldom receive their credit due. Yet, the ingenious use of a rather delicate media has resulted in a remarkable array of three-dimensional objects.  Frank Gehry's "Wiggle" side chairs; Isamu Noguchi's "Akari" hanging lamps; Tord Boontje "Until Dawn" curtains; Jan Pienkowski" pop-up books; Charles and Ray Eames "House of Cards"; Kay Sekimachi's paper bowls; Red Groom's "taxi" sculptures; paper dresses, recycled paper vases; artist books, paper maché; and vintage wallpapers are among the intriguing surprises offered.

The Book of Hours
exhibition_description: Gallery 344 will host a presentation of Books of Hours from the Institute's permanent collection produced in Flanders in the late 15th and early 16th centuries.  A Book of Hours is a lay person's prayer book read during private devotions. These books were small enough to be held in the hand, and were easily portable.  Many of the pages in these laboriously hand-written books were illuminated - literally "lighted up" - with miniature scenes and elaborate initials, painted in bright colors and gilded with gold and precious metals.  Preserved in closed volumes for centuries, illuminated manuscripts remain fresh and vivid examples of medieval artistic techniques.

exhibition_title: Southern Exposure: New Orleans and the Gulf Coast
exhibition_description:
As the world responds with both moral and financial support for the victims of hurricanes Katrina and Rita, The Minneapolis Institute of Arts also honors the wonderfully diverse communities of the Gulf Coast working to rebuild their lives.  Drawn from the museum’s permanent collection, Southern Exposure celebrates the rich cultural and artistic fabric that has defined New Orleans and the Gulf Coast for over 200 years and has created an essential, enduring place in the heart of the nation.   
This exhibition, including ceramics and paintings, will open at Orchestra Hall on October 14th as part of  “Art Spirit: A Benefit for Hurricane Relief,” which takes place on October 16th.  Photographs and works on paper from the MIA’s permanent collection will augment Southern Exposure when it opens in the General Mills Welcome Gallery on October 18, 2005.

exhibition_title: Banks with Bite: Selections from the Katherine Kierland Herberger Collection of Banks
exhibition_description: Katherine Herberger did not set out to have one of the most significant collections of antique still and mechanical banks in the country, but at the time of her death in 2003, her collection included more than 1,300 examples. The Katherine Kierland Herberger Collection of Banks has now found a permanent home at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts, where a newly dedicated gallery on the ground floor between the Family Center and classrooms showcases rotating exhibitions of the collection. The exhibition, titled “Banks with Bite! Selections from the Katherine Kierland Herberger Collection of Banks,” features more than one hundred examples of animal banks that are sure to delight visitors of all ages.

exhibition_title: Thoroughly Modern: the "New Woman" Art Students of Robert Henri
Villa America: American Moderns 1900-1950
exhibition_description:
Villa America: American Moderns, 1900-1950, organized by Elizabeth Armstrong, Orange County Museum of Art Deputy Director for Programs and Chief Curator, is drawn from the collection of Curtis Galleries, Inc., founder Myron Kunin, and will present over 85 paintings and sculptures from this collection to the public for the first time. The exhibition begins with a look at key American modernists working in Europe and New York during the first quarter of the 20th century. In these early years, artists such as Stuart Davis, Charles Demuth, Arthur Dove, Marsden Hartley, Gerald Murphy, and Georgia O'Keeffe, to name just a few, were reshaping our view of American art. In the early 1900s many of these artists traveled abroad, where they embraced experimentation to transform traditional subject matter into avant-garde statements of personal expression. After World War I, as New York began to eclipse Europe as the destination for creative people, American artists returned, and many artists from abroad moved to New York. 
This extended period of artistic innovation largely came to an end in the 1930s, after the stock market crash, followed by a more sober, realistic mode, with themes reflecting regional values and a new sense of social responsibility. Artists such as Romare Bearden, Paul Cadmus, Philip Evergood, Philip Guston, Reginald Marsh, and Ben Shahn celebrated an 'American Scene' creating powerful images of everyday American life. In the 1930s and 1940s American Regionalists John Curry and Grant Wood championed a nationalistic art that celebrated agrarian values and the search for American roots. George Ault, Charles Sheeler, and Niles Spencer, among others, returned to a form of classical realism to celebrate the American landscape in their paintings of the period.
In addition to offering a chronological overview of American modern art, Villa America will also include a selection of major figurative works by such American masters as Milton Avery, Robert Henri, Walt Kuhn, and Andrew Wyeth. Equally noteworthy will b

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions: Bowls with Punch
exhibition_description: Along with tea from China and chocolate from South America, an exotic beverage from India swept across the British Empire in the 17th and 18th centuries: punch.  A concoction of spirits, citrus, spices, sugar, and water, punch was made in hundreds of variations on this basic recipe.  From state dinners to tavern gatherings, it was the libation of choice for special occasions-particularly during the holidays.  As it grew in popularity, so too did its specialized bowls, ladles, cups, glasses, and mugs made of ceramic, silver, or glass.  The Institute will feature punch bowls from the 18th-20th centuries in the Bell Decorative Arts Court during this year’s Holiday Traditions exhibition, on view in the Period Rooms and at the Purcell-Cutts.  Costumed docents will offer tours from Thanksgiving through New Year’s.

exhibition_title: Remembering Gus Gustafson: Artist, Collector, Friend
exhibition_description: Remembering Gus pays tribute to artist and collector Gus Gustafson whose untimely death in 2003 shocked and saddened countless members of the Twin Cities art scene. The exhibition will feature selected works from Gus’ vast collection of works by contemporary Minnesota artists in addition to his own photographic works. Remembering Gus will be organized b a team of artists and curators with intimate knowledge of his collection and life (Thom Barry, Julie Hartley, Larry Marcus, Ann Marsden and Glen Hanson) the exhibition will be accompanied by a video documentary about Gus featuring many artists from the community as living testimony for his love of art, artists and life itself.

All Shook Up: Modernist Barware
exhibition_description: The cocktail-like jazz and the skyscraper-is an American invention. Capitalizing on the cocktail rage of the 1920s and `30s, a number of enterprising companies (American and European), produced an amazing array of barware including cocktail shakers, syphon bottles, trays, decanters, ice buckets and accompanying accessories. The exhibition focuses on modernist works produced by such major-league designers as: Normel Bel Geddes, Russel Wright, Lurelle Guild, Jean Puiforcat, among others.
