Supper with Shakespeare: The Evolution of English Banqueting
exhibition_description:
In collaboration with world-renowned English culinary historian Ivan Day, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts will present the exhibition, Supper with Shakespeare: The Evolution of English Banqueting, December 13, 2012 – March 31, 2013. The term “banquet” in the context of sixteenth and seventeenth century England meant a visually striking collection of after dinner sweet foods, preserves, and confections. In Shakespeare’s time (he died in 1616), such displays of culinary wonder were among the most magnificent in the history of British dining. Banquets were intended to impress and delight diners while the servants cleared the remains of the main feast, so they were often held in outdoor “banqueting houses” or in an intimate chamber such as the MIA’s Tudor Room.  
In 1923, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts installed the Tudor Room as the museum's first period room, calling it "the very embodiment of the spirit of the seventeenth century." Furnished with a rich assortment of tables, chairs, and case furniture that evoke the furnishings and lifestyle of Tudor England, the room’s oak paneling dates to about 1600. Once part of a private chamber used for eating, sitting, and entertaining guests, the room came to the MIA with a history of use in a manor in Suffolk, England. 
For Supper with Shakespeare, the Tudor Room will be laid out with a full banquet of period culinary delights hand-crafted by Ivan Day. The exhibition will continue in the adjacent Briggs Court, featuring dining related objects of silver, ceramic, and glass from the MIA’s collection, as well as an assortment of loan objects such as period cookbooks, food moulds, and kitchen utensils.  The whole will enchant art lovers and foodies alike!  
Planned programs include a “Supper with Shakespeare” public lecture by guest curator Ivan Day on Thursday, December 13, 2012 at 11:00 am, sponsored by the Friends of the MIA; a private Tudor-inspired feast curated by Ivan Day, date TBD, complete with a special Tudor inspired ale locally brewed for the occasion; and

exhibition_title: Luke Aleckson "U.N.P.A.C. (Uniform Non-coding Parallax Autostereogrammic Cyclopti-cryptograms)"
exhibition_description: Stereograms, also known by the popular brand MagicEye, are graphics that contain an image seen from the left and right eye perspective. When they are looked at in a certain way, their encoded images come off the page and appear as a floating illusion. Luke Aleckson is interested in how these low-tech images are designed to encode then release information. By themselves, the wall-mounted sculptures in his fascinating exhibition UNPAC (Uniform Non-coding Parallax Autostereogrammic Cyclopti-cryptograms) are complex wood abstractions carved using a home-made routing machine. But when they are looked at like stereograms, the image he has inserted into the piece will appear. In this case, visitors will see an image of the 8-foot cube Aleckson built in the gallery; it is made from a maple veneer that matches the same wood and stain treatment of the surfaces in the Target Wing rotunda and door jambs.

exhibition_title: Justin Quinn "Deeper Wonders Than the Waves"
exhibition_description: At the heart of Justin Quinn’s concept-driven art practice is an interest in disappearance and illegibility. His fastidious drawings, sculptures, and books are a collaboration with excerpts from classic literature but he has replaced the words with thousands of individual "Es", inserted gaps, and bent the lines to make the original text unreadable. He is exacting in how the resulting forms follow the precise word count of the original text, yet, like a concrete poem, turned them into abstract and architectural compositions of the narrative that spread the edge of the page. The silver-point mark making he uses in the large-scale graphite and ink drawings will slowly tarnish, turn to black, and no longer be visible on the hand-made paper. Also on display in “Deeper Wonders Than the Waves” are scattered floor sculptures are bent paper drawings that barely stand up as 3-dimensional forms. Finally, there is Quinn’s self-published book which is bound with hundreds of screen-copied prints of the same page.

exhibition_title: Andy Warhol and his Contemporaries: an urban milieu--New York in the 60s and 70s
Focus on a Masterpiece: Albrecht Dürer's Melencolia
exhibition_description: The MIA recently acquired a fine example of arguably the greatest engraving ever made. This exhibition is an in-depth look at the making and meaning of the work.

exhibition_title: Coming Out Party: Broc Blegen
exhibition_description: “Coming Out Party” will showcase new multimedia wok that includes ready-made and fabricated conceptual art pieces Broc Blegen has meticulously copied from original works of art. They are attributed to the original artists but have become part of his personal art collection; it’s his way of living with compelling artworks without the prohibitive cost of purchasing the originals. Blegen has included many familiar names in his collection, especially those artists interested in identity politics, such as Glenn Ligon, Jonathan Horowitz, and Jenny Holzer. The works in the show will provoke interesting questions about religion, gay rights, and the economics of art patronage and collecting.

exhibition_title: Remnants and Rumination: Binod Shrestha
exhibition_description: As a young art student growing up in Nepal, Binod Shrestha marched in a quest for democracy and later witnessed years of civil war between Maoist rebels and the ruling monarchy. From his new home in America, amid a global war on terror, these previous experiences continue to permeate his work. Taking frequent trips to visit family and friends in Nepal over the years, he has returned with recorded testimonies from others who have seen and suffered the violence firsthand. In Nine Steps dozens of his earthenware pots have been punctured and torn apart. Shrestha’s installations and smaller works, made of elemental materials such as mud, wood, and sand, are metaphors for the collective human bodies who have suffered from intense physical and political pressures.

exhibition_title: Winterlights at the Purcell-Cutts House 2012
New Pictures 7: Stan Douglas: Then and Now
exhibition_description: Stan Douglas is a photographer, filmmaker, and installation artist, whose works have been exhibited internationally, including in three Venice biennales and three dOCUMENTAs. After conducting intensive research, he restages historical events using actors, costumes, props, and sets. Douglas was awarded the prestigious Infinity Award for Art by the International Center for Photography in 2012.

exhibition_title: A Handsome Cupboard of Plate: Early American Silver in the Cahn Collection
exhibition_description:
The cupboard of early American domestic and presentation silver assembled by Paul and Elissa Cahn over some thirty years is unified by strong design, fine craftsmanship, and awareness on the part of the collectors for both the course of American history and the history of the craft in the colonies.
“A Handsome Cupboard of Plate” begins in Boston, with a c. 1690 caudle cup marked by the first native-born American silversmith—Jeremiah Dummer (1645-1718)—which has a history of ownership in the Tufts family of Massachusetts—proceeds to New York, with a robust tankard and a distinctive large fluted and gadrooned caster reflecting the Dutch heritage of that region marked by Bartholomew Schaats (1683-1758), and progresses to Philadelphia, where generations of the Quaker Richardson family supplied goods of the “best sort, but plain” to their clientele, including Lydia and Oswald Peel, who acquired an octagonal covered sugar dish and tea caddies ca. 1736.
Silver of the post-Revolutionary War era in the Cahn cupboard documents transitions to a new aesthetic that exploited available technology for rolling sheet metal and a neoclassical ornamental vocabulary. The shop of patriot Paul Revere Jr. notably utilized both new manufacturing techniques and the new ornament. These changes are apparent in the laurel-leaf wreath enclosing the dedicatory inscription on the Danielson Family commemorative tankard (c. 1783), and in the seamed, fluted, and swag-and-tassel engraved Adams-Quincy teapot with stand (c. 1790). In New York and Philadelphia, the shops of Myer Myers and Joseph Lownes (1758-1820) utilized the sleek, smooth, “flatted” (rolled) sheet silver in hooped tankards and canns, respectively.
The end of the second presidential term of George Washington in 1797 closes out the Cahn cupboard of plate. Myer Myers died in 1795; Joseph Richardson II became second assayer at the U. S. Mint (by Washington’s appointment), and Paul Revere Jr. left the artisan silversmith’s shop to preside over industrial production of bells, cannon,

exhibition_title: Picturing Poverty: Artistic Views of the Poor in the Baroque Era
exhibition_description:
During the 17th century, artists in Europe began looking to everyday life for their subjects, with special attention to the poor.
The plight of the impoverished came to the fore during the Thirty Years War (1618–48), which reduced broad swaths of Europe to subsistence living or starvation. People were also familiar with Gospel teachings that exalted the poor as inheritors of the kingdom of heaven. Jesus himself was born in a humble stable and had simple shepherds as his first visitors. Artist after artist depicted the Holy Family’s flight into Egypt, riding on a donkey and cooking over a campfire. A strong note of compassion informed the work of Stefano della Bella and Rembrandt, whose portrayals of wretched humanity in this exhibition often took on a remarkably personal character.
Many artists were able to find a sort of ragged dignity in the lower levels of society. They showed the poor in attitudes of industrious acceptance or stoicism, where a battered hat became a crown of virtue, a sign of resolute endurance of a miserable life. Such fortitude found adherents especially in France with the Le Nain brothers, whose sympathies are evident in the realism of their painting now in the Louvre, where poor farmers are portrayed, in all their deprivation and sad acceptance of poverty.
In other cases, an insistent attention to the decorative value of tattered and patched clothes—torn caps and shoes, wrinkles, sagging cheeks—suggests a colder curiosity, a simple pleasure in the representation of the picturesque, and a willingness to caricature misery.
As this exhibition demonstrates, artists interpreted poverty in many ways. For Adriaen van Ostade, it sometimes became the equivalent (both in cause and consequence) of spiritual misery. For William Hogarth, it would lead to the social denunciation described in his famous satire Gin Lane (1751). Whether the emphasis was on debauchery or the delineation of a frayed hem, the work of Baroque-era artists found the poor to be rich subject matter indeed.

exhibition_title: Seven Billion: Gregory Fitz
exhibition_description: This exhibition will be the debut of Gregory Fitz’s ambitious 3-part installation. Comprised of day-glo gestural landscapes, paintings made after Ansel Adams photographs, and cinder block table sculptures, “Seven Billion” is a response to the aesthetic projects of modern art and architecture. It’s no accident that Fitz’s work is made from economical materials such as insulation foam and chip board, or that he works so quickly. By doing so he wants to leave his decision making process visible and make a counter-point to the legacy of modern painters and sculptors. This leaves his work wide open for questions about the sacred value given art, the environmental concerns of art making, and the emphasis placed on craft and presentation. Fitz’s work has been part of group exhibitions at Form+Content, the Soap Factory and Weisman Art Museum.

exhibition_title: Isohyet, Isopleth: Katelyn Farstad and David Frohlich
exhibition_description: “Isohyet, Isopleth” is the second collaborative installation by Katelyn Farstad and David Frohlich. The title of the exhibition is borrowed from meteorological terms for lines on a map that are drawn in order to connect two or more points that share similar data. For two artists who are working together on a single exhibition, they are terms that allude to what might happen when different work styles merge in the space of a single exhibition. This show will be comprised of new paintings, prints, and sculptures, in various media. And through these works, audiences will be able see how their exhibition showcases their expanded practice and how they use concepts of idle time and desperation in their work. Both Farstad and Frohlic have exhibited extensively in the Twin Cities, including the Soap Factory, Art of This, and They Won’t Find Us Here.

exhibition_title: More Real? Art in the Age of Truthiness
exhibition_description:
The past century has been a period of unprecedented technological change and global social upheaval, causing a dramatic shift in our collective perception and experience of reality. Once agreed-upon beliefs, or “truths,” have been cast into doubt. As viewers of The Colbert Report know, we are living in an age of “truthiness,” where things we wish to be true are preferred to things we know are true. 
In this exhibition, contemporary artists from around the world use unexpected and diverse means to explore this modern conundrum. Their work can be divided into three general categories (often overlapping).
1—Deception and Play: From Trompe l’Oeil to the Authentic Fake
These artworks appear to be paintings or sculptures, but play with deception, navigating the borders of illusion and reality, between the authentic and the fake.
2—Reshaping the Real: Film, Memory, and the Virtual
This art uses film, video, and photography—media once thought to faithfully reproduce reality—to challenge assumptions about the physical and the virtual.
3—The Status of Fact: Unreliable Narrators, Parafiction, and Truthiness
Such artists create fictional identities, stories, and works that are presented as fact. 
The artworks in More Real? Art in the Age of Truthiness grapple with fascinating questions about the world today: How do we define what is real in a world where a multitude of media can radically reshape the original experience being depicted? What is the role of technology in such artistic expressions? How do we navigate between truthiness and deception in everyday life? When can fiction be truthful? 
In a time when the relationship between fact and fiction has never been murkier, the artists in “More Real?” explore a shifting sense of what is real and what is not, and the consequences of not understanding the difference. 
The exhibition More Real? Art in the Age of Truthiness, along with an accompanying 304-page catalogue and an interpretive website, provides a broad historical and cultural context for the questions that

exhibition_title: Joint Ownership 2012-2014
Synthesis 3D: Artist Multiples
exhibition_description: Selected from the MIA’s permanent collection and several private Minnesota collections, the exhibition features more than 40 artist multiples (reproducible art) from the 1960s to the present by leading international modern and contemporary artists.

exhibition_title: Drawings from the Bequest of Professor Alfred Moir
exhibition_description: Art historian Alfred Moir (1924-2010) of Santa Barbara has bequeathed his superb collection of art to the Minneapolis Institute of Art. The gift, which comprises over 250 works, includes drawings, watercolors, paintings, and prints. It is particularly rich in Italian old master drawings, with rare and outstanding works by such artists as Domenico Beccafumi, Annibale and Ludovico Carracci, Salvator Rosa, Giambattista and Giandomenico Tiepolo, and Federico Zuccaro, and will enrich the MIA’s holdings in this area exponentially. Alfred Moir was born and raised in Minneapolis, but spent most of his life in southern California. A specialist in 17th-century art, he was a professor at the University of California, Santa Barbara, where he taught for almost 30 years and retired emeritus in 1991. A selection of works from his collection will be featured in this exhibition.

exhibition_title: Rembrandt's Miniature World
exhibition_description: Rembrandt's artistic output was by no means confined to painting. In fact, many consider him the greatest printmaker of all time. Concurrently with "Rembrandt in America," the MIA will present an exhibition of the master's etchings. From quick sketches to elaborate baroque masterpieces, Rembrandt produced an astonishingly imaginative and diverse body of work. He studied beggars in the street, loved ones in his home, and unforgettably his own likeness--sometimes growling at us, sometimes costumed as a dandy, sometimes displaying full awareness of his own limitations. He recorded the world around him, from humble animals to majestic trees to dilapidated farmhouses. He reimagined the stories of the Bible, each time endowing the scene with drama or tender human emotion. This exhibition shows the mind of a genius at work.

exhibition_title: Bronze
Salvador Dali at Pompidou and MNCARS
Salvador Dali at Pompidou and MNCARS
Governor's Residence: 2012-2013
China's Terracotta Warriors: The First Emperor's Legacy
exhibition_description:
China's Terracotta Warriors: The First Emperor's Legacy brings to Minneapolis one of the greatest archaeological discoveries of our times. MIA was one of the first museums outside China to feature these figures in a small display held in 1985. Twenty-six years have passed since that exhibition. Every day, as the Chinese archaeologists toil away around the burial mound of one of the most remarkable figures in the history of China – the First Emperor – new finds and moments of the wealth of China’s ancient past are revealed. This is an epic story that has begun but is far from fully told.
Drawn from over thirteen institutions in China including the Museum of Terracotta Warriors and Horses, the Shaanxi Provincial Archaeological Institute and the Shaanxi History Museum, the exhibition is about an extraordinary man who has so impressed himself on the unfolding drama of the history of the Middle Kingdom. Born in a time of turmoil in China’s history, known as the Warring States period (475–221 BCE) this man was the founder of the short-lived Qin dynasty (221-206 BCE). He forged the seven warring states into one nation and himself from king of Qin Shihuang state to First Emperor. He left a legacy of a centralized and bureaucratic state that would be carried onto successive dynasties over the next two millennia.
Driven by his eagerness for immortality, from the moment Qin Shihuang ascended the throne of the Qin state at the age of thirteen he began to construct his burial. The complex plan and symbolic content of the mausoleum, as gradually revealed by the ongoing archaeological excavations, are far beyond anyone’s imagination, and beyond the boundary of the original protective outer wall which extends over 2km from north to south and nearly 1km from east to west. The Terracotta Army was discovered by accident in 1974 approximately 1km from the Emperor’s tomb mound by local farmers who were drilling a well. Shortly thereafter Chinese archaeologists excavated three pits containing, what is estimated to be, over 7,000 ter
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

exhibition_title: The World at Work: Images of Labor and Industry, 1850 to Now
exhibition_description:
For centuries, artists have explored the world of work and workers, creating enduring impressions of the challenges, triumphs, and life-affirming dignity of human labor. From romanticized visions of agrarian life, to sobering depictions of beleaguered manual laborers and miners, to scenes of worksites, factories, and industrial landscapes, these images reveal strikingly diverse interpretations of what it means to work. The subject is especially prevalent among graphic artists and photographers, who have exploited the power of reproduction to disseminate their ideas.

Selected entirely from the MIA’s permanent collection, the exhibition showcases more than fifty original prints, drawings, and photographs by prominent American and international artists and photographers active from the mid-nineteenth century to the present. The selection will include important examples by Jean-François Millet, Auguste Lepere, Edgar Degas, Pierre Bonnard, James McNeill Whistler, Muirhead Bone, Käthe Kollwitz, Rockwell Kent, Romare Bearden, Lewis Hine, Joseph Pennell, Louis Lozowick, Joseph Stella, Charles Sheeler, Harry Sternberg, Grant Wood, John Steuart Curry, Elizabeth Catlett, W. Eugene Smith, David Parker, James Rosenquist, Jim Dine, Donald Sultan, Herb Ritts, Sebastião Salgado, and others.

exhibition_title: Art in the Age of Globalization: Porcelain as a Global Commodity
exhibition_description:
Spanning the centuries and taken from every corner of the globe, the artworks in the galleries listed below explore significant aspects of the world’s evolving cultures. Divided into a series of installations, or “mini-shows,” each area has been designed around a specific narrative or theme related to globalization.


Globalization has resulted from the growth of modernization, the emergence of the Third World from colonization, advancements in communications, new technologies, and multinational trade, among many other factors. For better or for worse, it is one of the most significant and pervasive contemporary trends affecting our world today. 

Porcelain as a Global Commodity
By the end of the 19th century, porcelain played a role in disseminating new styles to consumers in Europe and the Americas, as designers applied the latest styles—from Japonisme to Art Nouveau—to affordable porcelain tableware. Contemporary ceramic artists have come full circle with artistic expression in this strong but fragile medium. Through a global awakening for exploration, market dominance, commerce, quality, and art, porcelain has now become commonplace—from the dinner table to the bathroom.

exhibition_title: Art in the Age of Globalization
exhibition_description:
Spanning the centuries and taken from every corner of the globe, the artworks in the galleries listed below explore significant aspects of the world’s evolving cultures. Divided into a series of installations, or “mini-shows,” each area has been designed around a specific narrative or theme related to globalization. 

Globalization has resulted from the growth of modernization, the emergence of the Third World from colonization, advancements in communications, new technologies, and multinational trade, among many other factors. For better or for worse, it is one of the most significant and pervasive contemporary trends affecting our world today.

Porcelain as a Global Commodity, StarTribune Atrium (G180)
By the end of the 19th century, porcelain played a role in disseminating new styles to consumers in Europe and the Americas, as designers applied the latest styles—from Japonisme to Art Nouveau—to affordable porcelain tableware. Contemporary ceramic artists have come full circle with artistic expression in this strong but fragile medium. Through a global awakening for exploration, market dominance, commerce, quality, and art, porcelain has now become commonplace—from the dinner table to the bathroom.

Outsourced (G262)
To some, outsourcing is an outgrowth of a hyper-connected world in which companies bring jobs to previously underserved markets. Others critique outsourcing because it neglects the needs of the domestic economy and labor force in the corporation’s home country.This installation posits the concept of outsourcing in the history of fine and decorative arts. From Giovanni Battista Tiepolo (1696–1770) and his workshop of assistants, to Andy Warhol (1928–87) and his famous Factory, to contemporary “flat pack” furniture, artists and designers have benefited from outsourcing portions of their production to skilled artisans in order to meet market demands. The works on view also raise questions about the aura of the “original,” authorship, and attribution, when a work is conceived by one artist or d

exhibition_title: Strangers in a Strange Land: Photographers' First Impressions
exhibition_description: Since the late 19th century, photographers have carried their cameras to unfamiliar neighborhoods and around the globe taking pictures of diverse people, places, and cultures. This exhibition features a range of classic masterpieces from the MIA’s collection that document photographers’ new encounters with foreign subjects and lands. The exhibition looks closely at how photographers translate a sense of culture, people, and place through imagery. It considers the power of photographic first impressions to shape historical representations of cultures that become lasting records of historical memory.

exhibition_title: Tools of the Trade: The William Howard Writing Desk from Kirkwood Plantation
exhibition_description: This writing desk was designed and created by William Howard and is a newly acquired object for MIA’s collection of African-American and American Folk Art. William “Willie” Howard lived and worked at Kirkwood Plantation in Madison County, Mississippi, first as a slave, then as a free man after the American Civil War. William McWillie and his wife Catherine built Kirkwood after arriving from South Carolina in about 1845. By 1857, McWillie had become governor of Mississippi and Kirkwood was a large cotton plantation with nearly 200 slaves. African Americans produced much of the material objects needed on the self-sustaining plantation, which included a smoke house, winery, bakery, and blacksmith shop. A skilled and no doubt valued carpenter and builder, William Howard remained on the plantation after the Civil War. While we have no record of his own sentiments regarding his continuation at Kirkwood, an 1869 letter from Mrs. McWillie to her son expresses her hope that, “…Willie may conclude to live ever here and give his precious wife and children as well as his beloved self a chance for a long and useful life.”

exhibition_title: letting go
Celestial Fragrance: Chinese Flower-and-Bird Painting
exhibition_description: This exhibition presents a fascinating tradition of Chinese flower-and-bird painting during the Ming and Qing dynasties (fourteenth through nineteenth century). Drawn from the holdings of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, the exhibition features a group of thirty stunning scrolls. It will show the diversity in style: some of the artists worked mainly with descriptive line and color on silk, pursued a meticulous, naturalistic rendering, a dazzling surface, and a sensuous effect, the others tended to favor a more expressive style, deliberately departed from naturalistic rendering and pursued impressionistic effects. The exhibition also explores the symbolism beyond the fragrance and natural beauty: often the motifs in these paintings were suffused with poetic overtones or imbued with social, religious, and political allusions, and have been used to express an endless range of meanings and sentiments.

exhibition_title: Saint Paul the Hermit: Restoration and Rediscovery
exhibition_description:
As recent research has confirmed, the statue of a Hermit Saint—which was acquired by the MIA in its altered position and with an attribution to Francesco Mochi in 1973—was indeed carved over a century later than originally believed.  It was the aim of this project to restore the statue to its original position and to restitute it to its rightful place in the history of Italian art by clearing up its attribution, original setting, and provenance. 
The exhibition will contextualize Baroque sculpture and enhance the public’s perception of and relationship to the sculpture through (1) examining the history and cultural moorings of Baroque sculpture, (2) telling the story of the quest for the work’s provenance, (3) explaining the traditional iconography of early Christian hermit saints, (4) illuminating the process of sculpture conservation as a means of also exposing the processes by which marble sculpture was created in its historical context, and (5) discussing the importance of the discipline of art conservation.

exhibition_title: Designing Nature: The Rinpa Aesthetic in Japanese Art
The Audacious Eye: Japanese Art from the Clark Collections
exhibition_description:
This first-look exhibition of over 100 highlights from the Clark Collections, recently acquired by the MIA, offers unusually rich and personal insights into the scope of Japanese art and the nature of connoisseurship. Bill and Libby Clark amassed one of the world’s finest collections of Japanese art according to their own finely honed interests, instincts, and idiosyncrasies. Not trends. Not markets. Not a particular time, place, or medium. They collected what they liked—what drew their audacious eyes.

 

This exhibition hints at the stunning variety and bold taste that accorded the Clarks’ endeavor, begun in the late 1970s, a kind of legendary status. Tucked in the agricultural valley of central California, their collection grew from frequent trips to Japan, stoking their enthusiasm for Japanese aesthetics—their home is a blend of Japanese and California Arts and Crafts styles. The combined collection of the Clarks and the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture reached almost 1,700 objects, ranging across 10 centuries and from paintings to sculpture, ceramics to textiles, woodblock prints to works of bamboo. They include important examples from every school of painting in Japan since the 16th century and from some of its most acclaimed living artists, including 80 pieces by ceramist Fukami Sueharu—the largest assembly of his sleek bluish-white porcelain in the world.

exhibition_title: Women in Soviet Art
Verbatim: Allen Brewer
exhibition_description:
Given the sheer and varied amount of antiquity and daily visitors in the MIA, Allen Brewer feels compelled to document the MIA visitors' perceptions of art and experience. To do so he will paint, draw and sculpt their descriptions of a (personally important) piece of art from the MIA’s collection. The outcome of this endeavor is not only an exhibition, but more importantly: an unvarnished series of interpretations that deal with the psychological phenomenon of selected memory and perception.
Brewer will invite visitors to fill out a simple description form, a request to isolate one piece within the entire collection that has a personal resonance, and then put it into words. Patrons will fill out the description form, which will be provided at the entrance of each gallery. He will collect the forms each week and create replica of the works, based on the descriptions, to be executed in his studio. The editing process of the pieces will be organic and judicious and in consideration of the MAEP gallery space.The weight, history and origin of words will alone dictate the outcome of each piece.

exhibition_title: The Progressive Pencil: George Elmslie's Prairie School Drawings
exhibition_description:
This exhibition commemorates the 100-year anniversary of the MIA’s crown jewel of Prairie School architecture, the Purcell-Cutts House, through a celebration of the design work of George Grant Elmslie (1869-1952). 

Having worked for Louis Sullivan (1856-1924) for nearly twenty years, Elmslie became well-versed in organic design principles, carrying them over in the exceptional work of the Minneapolis firms of Purcell, Feick and Elmslie (1910-1913) and Purcell and Elmslie (1913-1921). His contributions to the integrated decorative schemes developed by the firms often included a combination of elements such as terra cotta, stained glass, stenciling, furniture, murals, and sawed wood, to create a harmonic whole greater than the sum of its parts. 

Elmslie’s design drawing for the firm, rarely shown and minimally published, are delicate and beautiful studies, though they were meant to communicate to his partners and to the craftsmen who would execute these elements. The majority of these drawings are housed in the William Gray Purcell Papers at the Northwest Architectural Archives at the University of Minnesota. The exhibition will focus on the drawings as art objects, and as documents of the collaborative process of producing organic architecture. “The Progressive Pencil” would feature drawings for the Purcell-Cutts House and other notable Purcell and Elmslie projects such as the Merchants Bank of Winona, Minnesota (1911-13), along with historic photos and selected objects. Recent MIA acquisitions by Elmslie will also be featured, including the one-of-a-kind dining room suite for Mrs. Hanna (1915) with its wealth of detail.  It will include approximately 15-20 of George Grant Elmslie’s elegant design drawings, alongside photos and related objects from the MIA and local collections.

exhibition_title: It's New / It's Now: Recent Gifts of Contemporary Prints and Drawings
exhibition_description:
This exhibition showcases approximately 90 original prints, drawings, collages, books, and other works on paper by leading American and European artists, ranging in date from 1965 to 2011. All of the works to be shown were acquired by the MIA through recent gifts or bequests from individuals, businesses, and other organizations. Many of the editioned prints and artists’ books were produced in collaboration with nationally prominent print workshops and publishers. 
The exhibition is designed to acknowledge and celebrate the generosity of our collecting community, while underscoring their allegiance to the museum and support of the MIA’s public mission. Major donors to be represented in the show include Bob and Mary Mersky (gifted anonymously), Bob and Carolyn Nelson, Dar Reedy, Kate Butler Peterson, and the family of Mary H. Dayton. Other important donors include Barbara Kaerwer, Donna and Cargill MacMillan, Michael Root, Martin Weinstein, Dan Avchen, Roman Verostko (given anonymously), David and Mary Parker, Tom Rassieur, Mary Ryan Gallery, G & K Services, National Academy of Arts and Letters, Well Fargo Bank, among others.

exhibition_title: Battles in the Bedroom: Courtship and Marriage in Renaissance Italy
exhibition_description:
During the 15th century, the bedroom was the most private and symbolic room in patrician homes. It was the locus of conception, birth, sickness, and death. 

Leon Battista Alberti (1404–1472), the famous architect and theorist of the Renaissance, in his book “On the Family” (1432), describes how the newlywed husband gave his bride a tour of the house, finally entering the bedroom and locking the door. But his next move did not involve the rustling of fabric and the exposure of flesh. Instead, Alberti’s groom shows his new bride all the valuables—silverware, tapestries, clothing, and gems, as well as the splendid furniture where all these things would be secured. This passage makes clear how important the bedroom was at that time—a space of family privacy and splendor.

In the most luxurious palaces, tapestries embellished the bedroom walls and helped to control temperature. A small altar for devotion was always present, often an image of the Virgin Mary with her child, propitious for childbearing. The rooms had no closets, and cupboards or armoires had not come into use; instead, chests were the means of storage. Such chests—cassoni in Italian—were richly decorated or painted with fables or episodes from the history. They were a fundamental item of home decoration and considered the most symbolic piece of furniture connected with marriage. Great attention was therefore paid to the subjects represented upon them, allusive to the husband’s qualities, to the wife’s chastity and obedience, and to the family’s glory and wealth. Scenes of battle—reminders of hard-won power or triumphant moral virtue—were favored, and one assumes that they were also entertaining conversation pieces.

Clothing, wedding gifts, family documents, and other treasures were locked up in the cassoni. Smaller elegant boxes contained jewelry, sewing kits, or other personal items. The bed—the focal point of the room, and a very monument to lineage and fertility—was a complex machine, often placed on a raised platform that in some cases was a

exhibition_title: Trever Nicholas "Luma (Voronoi Cellscape)"
exhibition_description:
For his MAEP exhibition, “Luma (Voronoi Cellscape),” Trever Nicholas has created dozens of illuminated polyhedron sculptural shapes, each about the size of a basketball. These shapes are cut out of Styrofoam sheets, sanded into opaque geometric forms and lit from within by LED bulbs. The installation will produce a large-scale, gently glowing effect, with each shape resembling a crystalized milk bubble.
Nicholas’s previous installations have also been ambitious, room-filling accumulations made from thousands of individual parts. His materials have included blue plastic zip ties, inflated silvery Mylar balloons, and bright red, fuzzy pipe cleaners. The artist intends for these manufactured materials to mimic microbiological forms as they spread and grow throughout the gallery.

exhibition_title: UMWELT: Ryuta Nakajima
exhibition_description:
About 800 species of cephalopods (a class of marine animals) have been identified, the most common of which are squid and cuttlefish. They can change their colors and patterns instantly, whether for communicating or active camouflage, as their chromatophores (pigment-containing and light-reflecting parts of cells) are expanded or contracted.
Duluth artist Ryuta Nakajima has been studying the color-changing physiology and behavior of cephalopods in Japan. Using waterproof images of artworks from the MIA’s collection, he has photographed cuttlefish responding to and attempting to replicate the colors and patterns of European paintings, Japanese prints, and Islamic decorations. Nakajima has also created plastic molds of small cuttlefish, which he will mass-produce and paint in various patterns that mimic and stylize the cephalopod color-changing properties. Nakajima likens them to collectible Japanese Kubrick dolls.

exhibition_title: Sacred
exhibition_description: Sacred is the second in a series of innovative installations featuring imaginative combinations of contemporary and historic artworks throughout the museum’s Target Wing. For this installation, MIA curators probe the nature of the sacred within a secular, multi-faith society. By juxtaposing works of art from multiple times and places, “Sacred” invites visitors to explore historic expressions of the divine, the spiritual, the essential, the most-beloved, and to ponder the word’s meaning to their personal lives.

exhibition_title: Oskar Kokoschka: The Self in Focus
Chasing Matisse: American Moderns Under the Influence
exhibition_description: In the decade prior to the outbreak of World War I in 1914, dozens of American artists made their way to Paris to see, study and make art, eventually bringing the message of modernism home to the United States. It was Henri Matisse (French, 1869-1954) who had the most significant and lasting influence on these young American painters. This exhibition will examine how Matisse's art influenced American painters to revise their thinking about color and form, challenging the tradition of representational painting in the United States.

exhibition_title: Africa Now: Fashioning Personhood
exhibition_description:
Through the eyes of nine talented artists, this exhibition explores notions of personal style and cultural identity in contemporary Africa. Organized to mark the opening of the newly redesigned African galleries, it invites visitors to make connections between past and present perspectives found in the art of the African continent and the diaspora.
“Africa Now: Fashioning Personhood” challenges conventional ideas of African aesthetics and identity and also celebrates the wide circulation of ideas and influences that characterize the work of young African artists and designers. Their innovative contemporary work highlights the international reach of the African continent, featuring the rich exchange of African creativity with global cultures, periods, and styles.
exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas

exhibition_title: Alley Atlas: Andy Sturdevant
midday: Sarah Burns
Winterlights at the Purcell-Cutts House 2013
Shells: Magic and Science
exhibition_description:
Shells are among the first items a child collects, instinctively, while walking on a beach. Shells are common, abundant and, at the same time, can be precious and extremely desirable. Their sound, when drawn to the ears, is the evocative, infinite sound of the waves.
From the islands of the Pacific to African villages, from prehistoric shacks to the most sophisticated courts of Baroque Europe, the shells’ translucent texture and their complex and fantastic forms can be recognized in everyday objects, in decorative patterns, in figurative symbols and in an incredible variety of art works.
Shells assume a primary position in the naturalistic studies of the modern era, along with the discovery of new lands, and the improvement of optical instruments. Their forms attest not only to the perfection and magnificence of creation, but also visually make manifest mathematical logarithms; they also bring to life, and help to solve, the religious drama of the evolutionary problem.
Collecting shells can also be an expensive mania, as the first Mannerist Wunderkammern testify. There, nautilus and conches were mounted in precious metals, adorned with gems, “portrayed” by painters in still lifes, and displayed in magnificent cabinets—a pride of place in keeping with the importance of shells as an important field of naturalistic studies. 
Minneapolis and its surrounding area possess various treasures contained in the Minneapolis Institute of Arts and public libraries, including the Wangensteen Historical Library and the James Ford Bell Library—which, together, represent an immense patrimony of prints and precious antique books on natural history. 
The exhibition encompasses the passion for shells from the Wunderkammer to the post-Linnaean era. A small section is devoted to the still nowadays never-extinguished fever of shell-collecting.

exhibition_title: THE DREAM @ 50 Art Contest Semifinalists
MCAD@MIA
exhibition_description:
The Minneapolis Institute of Arts and Minneapolis College of Art & Design invited current MCAD students to submit proposals to MCAD@MIA, a unique opportunity for MCAD students to create a site-specific art installation at the MIA. The goal of this juried collaboration is to encourage art students to create new work that responds to the architecture, space, and/or diverse collections of the museum. The deliberations were not easy, as each proposal was unique, challenging and rewarding in different ways. But we were impressed with the overall quality of the proposals that reflected both the applicants’ strengths and the spaces of the MIA. We welcome and look forward to working with these talented students and continuing our partnership with Minneapolis College of Art and Design. 

After careful deliberations, the panel chose Josh Manoles and Linnea Stephan’s proposal for a wall installation of a pictographic character system derived from objects in the museum collection. Situated on the main staircase wall that connects all three floors of the museum, the pictographic system will highlight ties between different collections and provide a visually dynamic wayfinding guide.

The panelists for MCAD@MIA this year were: Christopher Atkins, Coordinator, Minnesota Artists Exhibition Program, MIA; Karen Wirth, Vice President of Academic Affairs, Minneapolis College of Art and Design; Jennifer Phelps, Director of the Burnet Gallery, Le Meridien Chambers, Minneapolis; Chris Larson, artist and professor University of Minnesota-Twin Cities. The panel and review process was facilitated by MAEP program assistant Lindsay Pulver and MFA student Lauren Wilcox.

exhibition_title: The Origin of "Boys Bathing" by Alexander Grinager
Kristina Estel, “Posture is Everything”
exhibition_description:
Kristina Estell's work examines the physical world through ideas that structure our relationship with the natural environment. Using a range of sculptural, installation, drawing and documentation techniques, she investigates the specific qualities of materials and objects to articulate a gesture or statement. 

Inspired by thoughts of accumulation, structure and failure, Estell will create a largescale silicone rubber sculptural installation for the MAEP gallery space. In my studio, the work will begin by making a series of structures out of cardboard shipping boxes of various sizes. The boxes will be stacked on each other and secured to shape solid mountainous, pyramidic forms. A range of these forms with gradated shaping and dimensions will be designed to sit centrally within the gallery space and reach a maximum peak height of up to twelve feet. Once the individual stack forms are constructed, I will apply multiple layers of silicone molding rubber to all of the exterior surfaces of the structures. The limp, empty and soft rubber shells will be given structure and rearticulated in the MAEP space by being suspended from hundreds of monofilament lines that will be attached from inside the form (with custom rubber hardware) at strategic corner locations. The replicated stacked box installation will become something of a mountainous marionette as it is lifted by lines from hundreds of points and pulled into shape while still revealing its true flaccid and sagging material nature.

exhibition_title: Identity Ink
Inscribe These Words
exhibition_description: In Jewish tradition, the inscribed word is believed to be a manifestation of the Divine and an invitation to participation. Drawing from the MIA’s own collection, this exhibition explores the use of inscriptions on Judaica objects. These inscriptions can be indicative of devotional practices, describe functional uses of the pieces, denote a personal connection, or demonstrate the very process of inscribing.

exhibition_title: Young People’s Ofrenda: Expressions of Life and Remembrance
31 Years: Gifts from Martin Weinstein
exhibition_description:
Martin Weinstein has given more than five hundred photographs to the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, in addition to numerous prints, paintings, and sculptures. 31 Years: Gifts from Martin Weinstein celebrate Martin’s thirty-one years of giving, from his first gift in 1982, Exchange by Jock Reynolds and Suzanne Hellmuth, to his most recent four in 2013, Paris (1989) by Elliott Erwitt; Falls 26 (2005) and Martin Weinstein, Minneapolis, Minnesota (2003) by Alec Soth; and Thomas (1987) by Robert Mapplethorpe.
The photographs highlighted in Martin’s collection are linked to many stories that are personal, institutional, and historic. One story is that of the collector, Martin Weinstein, a kid from Brooklyn, a sports fanatic, a teacher, a family man, and a prominent attorney, who discovers his passion for photography in the early 1970s and builds an outstanding collection. The other story is that of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, a museum that recognizes the power of photography as “the leading and only popular visual means” in the 1970s. A third story is of a curator, the late Carroll T. Hartwell (known as Ted), the MIA’s founding curator of photography, and his long-standing friendship with Martin.  And, finally, the most important story is that of a collection, the MIA’s photography and new media collection, which brings international photography to Minnesotans.

exhibition_title: Gifts of Modern and Contemporary Glass from Daniel Greenberg and Susan Steinhauser
Woman as Muse in the Age of Matisse
exhibition_description:
“What interests me most is neither still life nor landscape: it is the human figure.”—Henri Matisse  
For the most part, those human figures belonged to women. From 1889 until his death in 1954, Matisse made thousands of drawings, prints, paintings, and sculptures of women. He was following a timeless tradition that also animated many of his contemporaries. This exhibition presents a varied selection of two dozen prints and drawings, primarily by French, German, and American artists, all focused on the feminine. Some of the artists intentionally introduced radical distortions into their work for expressive purposes. Matisse attempted to capture his sublimated desire for his models. Others sought to reveal the intimate or inner world of women.

exhibition_title: Gown of Cloud & Rainbow: Miao Costumes & Jewelry from China
exhibition_description:
. . . Catching the pitch, matching the rhythms,
the holy ones come, they cover the sun,
wearing in gown of green cloud and white rainbow mantle . . .
Thus did the great Chinese poet Qu Yuan (340–278 BCE) describe the clothing of spiritual beings in his poem “The Lord of the East.” Ever since, in China a beautiful piece of clothing has often been called a “gown of cloud and rainbow,” and this phrase aptly describes the magnificent costumes and jewelry of the Miao people of China.
One of the largest ethnic minorities in China, the Miao are scattered among several provinces, but most live in the Guizhou/Yunnan plateau, a mountain area “beyond the clouds.” A Chinese word with the root meaning “young plant,” Miao is an official ethnic designation encompassing various groups that speak different dialects and have their own names for themselves—among them the Hmong, many of whom now live in Southeast Asia and various Western countries. In China, the majority of these groups commonly call themselves Miao.
The Chinese Miao people are famous for their embroidery skills and indigo dyeing techniques, and for underscoring the central roles of textiles and jewelry in their culture. Styles of Miao costume are diverse among the culture’s various sub-groups. A popular saying states “If you meet one hundred Miaos, you will see one hundred costumes.” Chinese anthropologists and art historians have noted that there are more than 170 different costumes from various geographic regions, which then fall into distinct categories. Even within the same village, the great variety of Miao dress and jewelry reflects the different functions of each costume: clothes indicate marital status, age, and ceremony.
The elaborate festival costumes and silver adornments constitute the most significant forms of Miao visual art. Such costumes are not only important possessions, but also considered the living visual art form of Miao culture. As in many cultures throughout Asia, Miao people express their identity through their textiles, clothing, and

exhibition_title: Art in Wisconsin
Pre-Raphaelites: Victorian Avant-Garde
Legacy: The Artistry of the Wyeth Family
Kano Sanraku and Sansetsu
Picasso Black and White
The Portrait of Vienna in 1900
Other Worlds: The Natural and Supernatural in Andean Art
exhibition_description:
As early as five thousand years ago, Andean people were producing art that interwove the natural and supernatural worlds. Through rituals and the intercession of priests and nobles, Andean people strove to create and maintain ayni (balance and harmony) within a dualistic cosmos. The works in this installation reveal how this was done, exploring the Andean belief in huaca (the sacred nature of things) and camay (divine action in the earthly realm).
This installation was developed by Professor William Barnes and his students of the University of St. Thomas, St. Paul MN.

exhibition_title: The Coated Splendor: Art of Chinese Lacquer (12th-19th centuries)
exhibition_description: Chinese lacquer is a natural varnish made from the sap of the lacquer tree. Exposed to air, it forms a plastic coat, resistant to water, acid or alkaline corrosion. Making lacquer work has a long history in China beginning in the late Neolithic period (c. 2,500 BCE). With more than thirty examples dating from the thirteenth to the nineteenth century, this exhibition celebrates the MIA’s important collection of Chinese lacquer. It presents the wide variety of forms, styles and techniques of lacquer works.

exhibition_title: The Infinite World: Chinese Figure Painting of the Ming and Qing Dynasties (14th-19th centuries)
MCAD@MIA: Aberration: Jamie Owens and Claire Victoria
Monica Haller: Beneath the Ground
exhibition_description:
Monica Haller, MIA’s current artist-in-residence, began her current project several years ago when her father removed piles of soil from a family property near Albertville, MN. That gesture became the starting point for some very interesting discussions about soil, and digging down into it, to discover geological and sociological histories. During her residency the project has grown as Monica has made strong connections with researchers at the University of Minnesota, which has been studying samples of Minnesota soil for years, and at the Minnesota Geological Survey, which maps Minnesota's geological history. 
She is using scientific data and her soil samples to find new ways of understanding artworks in the MIA's collection. Of particular interest is how knowledge of soil might affect visitors thinking about the ground on which the museum sits, as well as understand historical depictions of the landscape and objects made of materials from the ground. Monica's new commission, a series of soil sample "monoliths," will be installed throughout the museum and will be accompanied by series of docent tours opening on June 12.

exhibition_title: Through My Lens
Scents for the Soul: A Newly Acquired Havdalah Spice Box by Pope Pius VII's Silversmith
exhibition_description:
This spectacular havdalah spice box, recently acquired by the MIA, was made in Rome during a crucial period of emancipation. A time when Roman Jews first enjoyed full civil rights, albeit briefly.
It was made by Giovacchino Belli (1756–1822), the leading Roman silversmith of his time, who generally worked for the pope and high-ranking nobility. A symbol of religious freedom and a testament to the new status of the Roman Jewish community, the spice box epitomizes the neoclassical style, often associated with enlightenment and freedom. It is the same style employed by the young American nation in those years to symbolize its freedom and independence.

exhibition_title: Make It New, Again: Collecting History
exhibition_description: In the 1930s, American poet Ezra Pound famously encouraged modern artists to “make it new.”  Modernists did so through abstraction, 12 tone music, collage, photomontage, and other experimental approaches to the visual arts, film, dance, and architecture.   Today, to make it absolutely new is almost impossible given the sheer quantity of art produced since Pound’s slogan.  Still, contemporary artists certainly make art that is new, again.  And historic artworks acquire new meanings in our time.  This photography exhibition will feature a selection of recent museum acquisitions by Richard Avedon, Stan Douglas, Marco Breuer, and Margaret Bourke-White, among others – many will be presented in the MIA galleries for the first time – in an innovative installation that reveals how powerful images acquire new and provocative meanings in different historical situations.

exhibition_title: Young People’s Ofrenda: Expressions of Life and Remembrance
Giovanni Segantini: Il ritorno a Milano
The Library of El Greco
Jonathan Bruce Williams
exhibition_description: The driving principle of Jonathan Bruce Williams MAEP exhibition will be to display the science and technology of vision. He creates fascinating sculptural installations that re-present digital and analog images and "utilize photography as a technical and philosophical strategy." Most recently, he has been interested in ocular phenomena such as the persistence of vision, linear perspective and the stereoscopic illusion. For example, images will flicker, flash and appear stereoscopically with the aid of new and vintage machinery. Compositional elements, such as the symbolism of Americana and the history of photography, create formal affinities between the beacon of a lighthouse and a movie projector, or a picket fence and a zoetrope.

exhibition_title: Imperial Nature: Flora, Fauna, and Colonialism in India
exhibition_description: Two different approaches to understanding and depicting nature melded—with beguiling results—as the long interlacing of British and Indian cultures on the subcontinent came to a head in the 17th and 18th centuries, an uneasy period of spreading colonial rule. This exhibition showcases these unique representations of nature, commissioned from Indian artists by Indian princes and increasingly powerful European colonial patrons—an artistic and scientific confluence that forever reshaped the way we view the natural world.At the heart of the exhibition are 10 “Lady Impey” paintings on loan from Bill Clark. A British colonialist in Calcutta, Lady Mary Impey commissioned Indian painters to illustrate birds from her private menagerie, resulting in more than 200 images that owe as much to European natural science as India’s rich painterly tradition.
exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art

exhibition_title: Undead
How to make a world: Jaron Childs
exhibition_description:
Childs will present a new series of hyper-realistic & finely details paintings, based on his own photographs that are a rejoinder to contemporary attitudes about beauty in painting. He has done this by carefully choosing images that both test the limits of what is an acceptable level of sentimentality for critical art, and offer visual pleasures that also contain sensations of alienation and loss. With a relatively small number of works, "How to Make a World" is meant to engage the various and contradicting claims made on painting regarding beauty, artistic merit, and its relevance as a medium. 
The driving principle of Jonathan Bruce Williams MAEP exhibition will be to display the science and technology of vision. He creates fascinating sculptural installations that re-present digital and analog images and "utilize photography as a technical and philosophical strategy." Most recently, he has been interested in ocular phenomena such as the persistence of vision, linear perspective and the stereoscopic illusion. For example, images will flicker, flash and appear stereoscopically with the aid of new and vintage machinery. Compositional elements, such as the symbolism of Americana and the history of photography, create formal affinities between the beacon of a lighthouse and a movie projector, or a picket fence and a zoetrope.

exhibition_title: Finland: Designed Environments
exhibition_description:
This exhibition looks at the explosion of creativity in Finnish design from the last fifteen years. Nearly every aspect of life in Finland incorporates thoughtful design thinking, and sensitivity to form and material. The name Designed Environments reflects the many aspects touched by design in Finland today, from home interiors, to the body, to city streets, to food.
Finland: Designed Environments presents a selection of the most elegant, artistic, and thought-provoking objects and projects by Finnish designers, craftspeople, and architects. These objects share an inherent practicality, but are thoughtfully designed for an elevation of the user’s experience. Strong undercurrents in the exhibition include: the use of natural and local materials; respect for and closeness to nature, with an ecological emphasis; a high level of quality in all aspects; and a sense of wonder. Finland: Designed Environments is the first significant museum-organized exhibition outside Finland since the 1990s to examine the breadth of current Finnish design.
The exhibition Finland: Designed Environments will encompass furnishings, fashion, and craft, as well as architecture and urbanism. It will also address emerging and noteworthy areas of sensory design, graphic design, and systems design, as well as the intersection of design and food, all actively being addressed by Finland’s design community. Drawing upon the richness of the forward-thinking design community in Finland, the exhibition includes a number of projects that were a part of World Design Capital Helsinki 2012 (a bi-annual international designation awarded by the International Council of Societies of Industrial Design).

exhibition_title: Finland: Designed Environments
exhibition_description:
This exhibition looks at the explosion of creativity in Finnish design from the last fifteen years. Nearly every aspect of life in Finland incorporates thoughtful design thinking, and sensitivity to form and material. The name Designed Environments reflects the many aspects touched by design in Finland today, from home interiors, to the body, to city streets, to food.
Finland: Designed Environments presents a selection of the most elegant, artistic, and thought-provoking objects and projects by Finnish designers, craftspeople, and architects. These objects share an inherent practicality, but are thoughtfully designed for an elevation of the user’s experience. Strong undercurrents in the exhibition include: the use of natural and local materials; respect for and closeness to nature, with an ecological emphasis; a high level of quality in all aspects; and a sense of wonder. Finland: Designed Environments is the first significant museum-organized exhibition outside Finland since the 1990s to examine the breadth of current Finnish design.
The exhibition Finland: Designed Environments will encompass furnishings, fashion, and craft, as well as architecture and urbanism. It will also address emerging and noteworthy areas of sensory design, graphic design, and systems design, as well as the intersection of design and food, all actively being addressed by Finland’s design community. Drawing upon the richness of the forward-thinking design community in Finland, the exhibition includes a number of projects that were a part of World Design Capital Helsinki 2012 (a bi-annual international designation awarded by the International Council of Societies of Industrial Design).

exhibition_title: New Pictures 9: Rinko Kawauchi
exhibition_description:
Rinko Kawauchi’s first museum exhibition in the United States shows why she’s one of the most important and popular female photographers working in Japan today. Kawauchi’s unique installation of photographs at the MIA capture ordinary, fleeting moments of light and daily life, the photographs evoking everything from wonderment to the grotesque. A picture of a child breastfeeding. Ants carrying a grain of sugar. A tiny chrysalis on a blade of grass. She views the world with a playful, thought-provoking, and critically detached curiosity.
Kawauchi is also well known for her photography books, which present an evocative sequence of images unfolding on every spread. She has produced 15 photo books since 2001, including Light and Shadow (2012) and Illuminance, Ametsuchi, Seeing Shadow (2012). Now living and working in Tokyo, Kawauchi has exhibited around the world, including a recent solo exhibition at the prestigious Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Photography in 2012.

exhibition_title: Restoring a Masterwork III: Max Beckmann's Blind Man's Buff
exhibition_description:
Max Beckmann’s Blind Man’s Buff is the largest, and arguably the most important of his nine great triptychs. The work was painted during his exile in Amsterdam between September 1944 and October 1945 under difficult wartime circumstances. In his journal, Beckmann refers to air raids and lack of food, coal and electricity; in fact, much of the triptych was painted by candlelight. The MIA acquired Blind Man’s Buff in 1955. It is consistently counted among the top five important artworks owned by the museum. Unfortunately, despite its controlled environment, the fragility of the three panels increases yearly, due to structural instability and surface deterioration. 

The conservation treatment of the Max Beckmann triptych has been generously funded by Bank of America's Art Conservation Project, and will be conducted over a four-month period by the MIA’s art conservation provider, the Midwest Art Conservation Center (MACC), and under the supervision of the MIA. MACC is a non-profit regional conservation facility housed within the museum, making frequent conservator-curator consultation throughout the treatment possible.

exhibition_title: Chad Rutter: Floodplain
exhibition_description: Chad Rutter is an artist and bookmaker whose work explores American material and cultural geography through a wide range of media, including photography and sculpture. His fascinating MAEP exhibition will present a running text of Henry David Thoreau’s "Walden" on a set of highway message boards. By converting this classic meditation on the beauty of wilderness and creative isolation into tiny 3-line bits of text, Rutter’s installation will conflate the private and slow-paced act of reading with the fast-lane drive through the natural landscape.  It will also reflect on the Rutter’s understanding of transcendentalist philosophy, which he links to American values of individualism, car culture and exploration.

exhibition_title: Audible Edge
Art Expanded 1958-1978
American Impressionism, A New Vision, 1880-1900

Marks of Genius: 100 Extraordinary Drawings from the Minneapolis Institute of Arts
exhibition_description:
The Minneapolis Institute of Arts is home to over 2,000 drawings, watercolors, and pastels, yet the collection is largely unpublished and not well known. In this large and varied assortment of works is a superb group of drawings, works of exceptional quality that include some of the museum’s key masterpieces. The exhibition features 100 outstanding drawings, ranging from the 15th to the 21st centuries, by European and American artists, including both celebrated masters and others who deserve to be better known. The show presents beautiful drawings from the permanent collection to both local and national audiences and also explores the many roles of drawing from study, to recording moments of inspiration, to problem solving, to medium of choice for finished works of art. All the drawings come from the MIA’s collection.    


The exhibition includes 100 drawings executed in a variety of media by a range of artists, including Ludovico Carracci, Baldassare Franceschini, Giovanni Domenico Tiepolo, Antoine Watteau, Jean-Honoré Fragonard, Jean-Baptiste Greuze, Jacques-Louis David, Pierre Paul Prud’hon, Anne-Louis Girodet, Eugène Delacroix, Thomas Gainsborough, George Romney, Edouard Vuillard, Edgar Degas, Eva Gonzales, Henri Matisse, Lovis Corinth, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Käthe Kollwitz, Otto Mueller, Emil Nolde, Egon Schiele, Piet Mondrian, Edward Hopper, John Marin, Grant Wood, Roy Lichtenstein, Jasper Johns, Andy Warhol, and Edward Ruscha.

Andy Messerschmidt - Delta Delta Delta Force
exhibition_description: Andy Messerschmidt is an occultist who is fascinated by supernatural beliefs and the visual culture of mystical ceremonies. His chaotic installations draw from his stockpile of holiday ephemera, which includes miles of wrapping paper and dozens of Christmas tree skirts. Obscure religious iconography is layered throughout the wall collages and sculptures, creating a riot of patterning and appropriated symbolism that find the divine in throwaway materials. The exhibition title, Delta Delta Delta Force, connotes secret letter and military organizations that have their own initiation rites and symbolism. The gallery will be lit with a deep red glow, and a low delta wave hum will emphasize Messerschmidt’s surreal, free-associative imagery.

exhibition_title: Matthew Zefeldt – Repetition, Simulation, Repetition
exhibition_description: Mathew Zefeldt’s brightly colored acrylic paintings of 16-bit graphics and textures are appropriated directly from vintage video games he played as a teenager, classics such as DOOM, Super Mario Brothers, and Castle Wolfenstein. The themes of life and death, both real and virtual, are repeated throughout his work, as seen in his use of traditional memento mori, such as funerary reliefs and vanitas paintings. It may appear that the bricks and hero’s face in “When You’re Dead, You’re Dead” are cut, then pasted, but each detail is meticulously handpainted. Gallery walls covered floor to ceiling with sheets of 16-bit brick vinyl wallpaper will complement the paintings.
